'')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_202326604" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/202326604" />    <a title="Katya" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4324634-katya"><img alt="Katya" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1285183076p2/4324634.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/202326604?book_show_action=false">Aug 26, 2011</a>      <a title="Katya" class="user" name="Katya" href="/user/show/4324634-katya">Katya</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9789542701514" href="/book/show/7377912">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4324634-katya?shelf=horrible-best-friends">horrible-best-friends</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4324634-katya?shelf=teen-lit">teen-lit</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4324634-katya?shelf=2011">2011</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4324634-katya?shelf=oh-come-on">oh-come-on</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4324634-katya?shelf=kudos-for-the-worldbuilding">kudos-for-the-worldbuilding</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4324634-katya?shelf=the-harry-potter-challenge">the-harry-potter-challenge</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4324634-katya?shelf=holy-hell">holy-hell</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer202326604" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer14785899369601937852">Well, it's here folks. The final showdown, at least for me. The final review and the finish to my self-imposed Harry Potter summer challenge. Much like many people, I read the whole series, only in my case, it wasn't in preparation for the movie. Rather, it was me finally coming back to finish what I started ten years ago with these books.<br><br>And what's the final verdict?<br><br>It wasn't so bad.<br><br>*total outrage*<br><br>Yes, yes, I imagine you expected me to spew venom all over the place, or, maybe you didn't and are</span>  <span id="freeText14785899369601937852" style="display:none">Well, it's here folks. The final showdown, at least for me. The final review and the finish to my self-imposed Harry Potter summer challenge. Much like many people, I read the whole series, only in my case, it wasn't in preparation for the movie. Rather, it was me finally coming back to finish what I started ten years ago with these books.<br><br>And what's the final verdict?<br><br>It wasn't so bad.<br><br>*total outrage*<br><br>Yes, yes, I imagine you expected me to spew venom all over the place, or, maybe you didn't and are now sniggering at my having fallen, once again, under Rowling's spell.<br><br>To both camps: KEEP YOUR SHORTS ON, I'm not finished.<br><br>Yes, it wasn't so bad. For instance, we finally, finally, finally see some character development in Harry, and even the Ron/Hermione romance wasn't as bad as I thought it might be. SNAPE! NEVILLE! DRACO! Those three alone are enough of a motivation for anyone to read the series. In fact, I'd like to point them out as examples of how to write good male characters. Alyson Noel, take note!<br><br>And yes, I was also very much emotionally vested in these characters. I loved all of them, and how wonderfully they interact. I was pleasantly surprised with Percy, who experienced some very impressive character development, as well as Dumbledore, who finally got knocked off his pedestal and was shown, rather, like a character and not some flawless Yoda-like saint. <br><br>That said, there are shortcomings in this book. In fact, some of its greatest strengths are also its greatest weaknesses.<br><br>#1 Harry<br><br>Alright, so we finally get to see the Boy Who Lived to Be a Pain in the Arse to evolve into a character. I loved how Harry grew more responsible in this book, and how he learned that sometimes you have to do what you have to do. My question, though, is this: Why did it take him six and a half books to get there? I know he grows throughout the series, but it's only in this one where he drops the whining and mans up. In a way, throughout the series, he's very much a child, even with all the ordeals he has experienced.<br><br>#2 Ron/Hermione<br><br>I still maintain that Hermione is a superior character to both Harry and Ron. I mean, for the love of God, she <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[ removes herself from her parents' memories just to keep them safe, and doesn't break down, even when she's being tortured  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span>. Not to mention the dozens of times she has saved everyone's lives, and how she focuses on the bigger picture instead of on her own feelings when the situation calls for it. <br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1379762287i/209596._SY540_.jpg" width="446" height="578" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Rowling really worked on making the romance between Ron and Hermione more believable in this book, but much like Harry, it comes about six and a half books too late. And don't tell me Ron was a prat to her because it's in the character of teenage boys and they bonded through trauma - if that's the case, then explain the epilogue (which I will get to in a minute).<br><br>#3 Dumbledore<br><br>So in book 6 we were seeing the cracks in Dumbledore's saint-like image, but it's not until book 7 that we get a glimpse of the man that he really was. I loved this development, as it showed a lot about his motivation and past.<br><br>As for the matter of Dumbledore's homesexuality... I admit I was sceptic when I heard it first. Now that I read the book, I think I kinda see it. There is definitely something there, and I can also see it couldn't really be obvious - at the time, it was very unlikely that Dumbledore could have acted on his feelings, and then afterwards... yeah.<br><br>Now that I read it, I realize Rowling couldn't have elaborated on that aspect of Dumbledore because that's not the point of the series. The point of the series is the power of love and humanity over evil, not the romantic subplots. <br><br>Although, again, that doesn't fit in with the epilogue, which I will get to... eventually.<br><br>#4 The Amount of Hammy Deaths in the Book<br><br>Where do I begin with this? Okay, you know how Mockingjay is sometimes referred to as 'tragedy porn'? Well, this book borders on it. I mean in the first fifty pages, the owl dies. THE OWL DIES! Right after Harry gives her a nice tour down memory lane. I mean, poor Hedwig!<br><br><span>[image error]</span><br><br><i> Um, not that one, but... actually... yeah, poor Hedwig. </i><br><br>And that's not even the worst of it. The battle for Hogwarts, in its own right, is as horrible as it comes. The deaths of so many wonderful characters <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[ Oh, Lupin! Oh, Tonks! Oh, Colin!!! Oh, FRED!  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> alone are enough to bring tear to the eye. A friend of mine accused me once of wishing some character or another had died in the place of another, and I guess that's not wholly fair because even the most annoying ones shine during the battle. <br><br>But... some of those deaths were so grisly, and then followed by a moment that was supposed to be... cute? <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[ One moment, we have Lavender being savaged by a werewolf, and in the next, Treloni is killing Death Eaters by tossing spheres! What. The. Fuck!  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> How is this even remotely acceptable? What was Rowling going for with this? I've heard people say that the series grew with the books, but this? Are we trying to write REALISTICALLY here? Because... um...<br><br>#5 The Plotholes<br><br>Rowling's clearly not squeamish about killing off her characters. And she's not afraid of making the series dark. So why the hell is Harry alive? There was this huge buildup towards a heroic sacrifice which would save the whole world, and then we get this ridiculous cop-out that is so convoluted I'm not even going to try and get in to. Of course, it allows us a whole chapter where Dumbledore's ghost explains everything to our clueless hero, who, instead of letting his feelings run free and telling him to go fuck himself, forgives him nicely and goes back to the land of the living. <br><br>And so on, and so on. If I went back to explain every plothole of this book, we'd be here till tomorrow. My point is, this victory seems to be based on quite a lot of nice little conveniences. I mean, how nice of Harry to explain how he's won to Voldemort right before he kills him, or that his self-sacrifice (even if he never died) protected the whole frickin' school!<br><br>#6 The Epilogue<br><br>How many people have complained about this? Can't count? Neither can I? So we get this victory which came along through the bloody sacrifice of so many, and then, nineteen years later, our heroes are living the dream, with children and white picket fences? Really?<br><br>Say what you will about the ending of Mockingjay, but at least it was sensitive to the trauma of war and the horrors the heroes went through. The Deathly Hallows is a tale of pain and loss which ends with an overly cute pink bow on top. Like Severus Lawliet said in her review, where's the emotional scarring? Hermione was tortured in the same manner as Neville's parents. Did Bellatrix just not have enough time to scar her permanently? <br><br>I realize that all this makes me look like a... rather unpleasant person.<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1380357679i/708909.jpg" width="270" height="321" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><i> Yeah... </i><br><br>But I just don't get what Rowling was going for with this book. Did she want the series to grow from one genre to another, like her characters? From a fun children's book to a dark, fantasy epic? Is the story really that realistic? Dragons and goblins and magic aside, I mean. <br><br>I see the merits of her book. I'm just saying that if she went through the trouble of setting up a tragic ending, maybe she should have gone through with it. <br><br>So that was the end of my little HP challenge. What do I think of the series as a whole? Decent. I'm sure it'll go down as a children's classic. And, as with most classics, it's best not read too much into it.<br><br>Now, if you'll excuse me, I'll go read some happy endings.<br><br><a href="http://www.fanfiction.net/s/1985577/1/Simply_Irresistible" rel="nofollow">Snape</a><br><br><a href="http://www.fanfiction.net/s/2530576/1/Once_in_a_Blue_Moon" rel="nofollow">Lupin and Tonks</a><br><br><a href="http://www.scribd.com/doc/7021319/Draco-Malfoy-The-Amazing-Bouncing-Rat" rel="nofollow">Draco and Hermione</a></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></span>  <a data-text-id="14785899369601937852" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review202326604">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link202326604"  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_629131674" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/629131674" />    <a title="AnHeC the Paperback Obliterator" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/20781309-anhec-the-paperback-obliterator"><img alt="AnHeC the Paperback Obliterator" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1384719838p2/20781309.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/629131674?book_show_action=false">Jan 08, 2014</a>      <a title="AnHeC the Paperback Obliterator" class="user" name="AnHeC the Paperback Obliterator" href="/user/show/20781309-anhec-the-paperback-obliterator">AnHeC the Paperback Obliterator</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9788372782809" href="/book/show/5929499-harry-potter-i-insygnia-mierci">review of another edition</a>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer629131674" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17623691054201085480"><b>word count: 198,227<br><br>rating: it's the pure fun of the idea, that magic could be just around the corner<br><br>*sobbing uncontrollably* </b><br><br>How can people not understand the craze? The shortest explanation I can give is a quote from one of my favourite books, which someone added pretty spot-on gifs to, so it would be a shame not to share it ^^ (*I take no credit)<br><br><br><br>"It's like in the great stories, Mr. Frodo.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963653.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>The ones that really mattered.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963654.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>Full of darkness and danger they were.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963655.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>And sometimes you didn't want to know t</span>  <span id="freeText17623691054201085480" style="display:none"><b>word count: 198,227<br><br>rating: it's the pure fun of the idea, that magic could be just around the corner<br><br>*sobbing uncontrollably* </b><br><br>How can people not understand the craze? The shortest explanation I can give is a quote from one of my favourite books, which someone added pretty spot-on gifs to, so it would be a shame not to share it ^^ (*I take no credit)<br><br><br><br>"It's like in the great stories, Mr. Frodo.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963653.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>The ones that really mattered.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963654.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>Full of darkness and danger they were.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963655.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>And sometimes you didn't want to know the end.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963656.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>Because how could the end be happy?<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963657.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>How could the world go back to the way it was when so much bad had happened?<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963658.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>But in the end, it's only a passing thing, this shadow.<br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1388961497i/7963659.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><img src="https://s3.amazonaws.com/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1388963761r/7964038.gif?14797287661557" class="gr-hostedUserImg hostedImg" data-src="https://s3.amazonaws.com/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1388963761r/7964038.gif" style=";display:none;" data-error="[image error]" onerror="$j(this).loadHostedImage();" onload="$j(this).loadHostedImage();"><img src="/assets/loading-trans.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg loadingImg"><br><br><br>Even darkness must pass.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963660.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>A new day will come.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963661.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>And when the sun shines, it will shine out the clearer.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963662.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>Those were the stories that stayed with you.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963663.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>That meant something, even if you were too small to understand why.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963664.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>But I think, Mr. Frodo, I do understand. I know now.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963665.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>Folk in those stories had lots of chances of turning back,<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963666.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>only they didn't.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963667.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>they kept going<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963668.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>Because they were holding on to something...<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963669.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>There's some good in this world, Mr. Frodo.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963670.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>And it's worth fighting for."<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963671.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>It's over. And I feel empty. Hogwarts it truly my home. This story is a precious part of me, as real as any other experience. I believe it will stay with me forever. It's not perfect, of course it's not, but to us that grew up alongside those characters it's special.<br><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963672.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963673.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1388961497ra/7963674.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>If you wish to read some of my random thoughts on this book, go there: <a target="_blank" href="http://anhec.booklikes.com/post/750430/-sobbing-uncontrollably-it-s-the-pure-fun-of-the-idea-that-magic-could-be-just-around-the-corner" rel="nofollow">http://anhec.booklikes.com/post/75043...</a><br><br>Here I'll mention only two things.<br><br>Neville: that one is beyond words. I think there's a bit of Neville living in each one of us. He's a true underdog of the story. He's scared, full of doubts, doesn't believe in himself, tries to meet the expectations of family and teachers, but always falls short. He can never quite measure up. Always insecure, always struggling. And yet he knows the difference between right and wrong and is willing to fight for it. To die for it. He knows who he is, who he wants to be. He finds his strength, he finds passion, he finds what he's good at and makes friends. The way he wasn't willing to compromise and stood up to his friends (after risking first a lot to warn them) is commendable. That is something Lupin didn't know how to do. He's got what young Dumbledor was missing. Ron, George, Harry... they all lose the sight of their goal, of priorities upon witnessing death and tragedy. What does Neville do? What Harry asked him to. He stands up to Voldemort and in this precarious situation, with a burning hat on his head, when he's about to die, he kills the snake. <b>He decides to do what Harry asked him to do even if it's the last thing he'll do in his life, even though he has no idea why was it important at all.</b> Harry wanted to know, needed to know 'why'. He felt entitled to this knowledge.The more I think about Neville the more I love and admire him. <br><br><i>"In a world of leaders and followers, there are some who donU+2019t attempt to fit either mold, and it is those distinct few who really determine the future of us all. That is what Neville Longbottom can teach us."</i><br><br><br>Snape: do I even have to tell you? He isn't a good guy - he's an asshole with serious anger management problems. <br><br>Does he love Lily? Yes and no, he's kind of obsessed, but she always represented something good in his life. It's not empty. Is he, as a young man, compassionate at all? Pff, nope. Does he change completely? NO! He hates Harry! To the very end! He's not angry abut the boy dying, but about feeling cheated out of his purpose in life! Something he was holding on to. Or is he? We never truly know! We don't ever learn the whole truth about him; we can only guess and assume. <b>This is one of the most wonderfully complex characters I've ever encountered.</b> You kind of hate him, but also admire his determination and dedication. Not to mention - you feel sorry for him, sorry for a boy that grew emotionally far, far too late. But in his twisted way he cared, he cared about the Order of the Phoenix, he cared about Dumbledore, he cared about the difference between right and wrong (after years of growing and changing, but still, he got there). What he did... It's beyond comprehension. Harry was ready to die, but before that he had lived. People knew him, loved him. Snape gave up EVERYTHING, ended up alone and despised, carrying great responsibility on his shoulders. I hope the extent of Snape's sacrifice was appreciated in the end. I really do.<br></span>  <a data-text-id="17623691054201085480" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review629131674">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_629131674" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 629131674, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">8 comments</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/629131674?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=7">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_629131674' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/629131674/comments?reverse=true">View all 8 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_629131674' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 629131674, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_852497588" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/852497588" />    <a title="virgodura" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/3065234-virgodura"><img alt="virgodura" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1463075305p2/3065234.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/852497588?book_show_action=false">Oct 25, 2015</a>      <a title="virgodura" class="user" name="virgodura" href="/user/show/3065234-virgodura">virgodura</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3065234-virgodura?shelf=novel-novella">novel-novella</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3065234-virgodura?shelf=sff-etc">sff-etc</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3065234-virgodura?shelf=2014">2014</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3065234-virgodura?shelf=british-lit">british-lit</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3065234-virgodura?shelf=childrens-ya">childrens-ya</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer852497588" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4942033597621415293">Reading this for the first time as I abandoned the series after the release of HBP so this review is my liveblog.<br /><br />In no particular order, good things:<br />1. Harry's death scene<br />2. Snape dying at the hands of Voldemort (very appropriate)<br />3. The Dursleys (always good, tbh)<br />4. Draco <br />5. Kreacher, to a degree. It's a nice idea, but it's profoundly unconvincing.<br />6. Remus guessing that the death eaters knew which Harry was Harry Potter as expelliarmus is seen as Harry's signature move. Hilarious. And true. One</span>  <span id="freeText4942033597621415293" style="display:none">Reading this for the first time as I abandoned the series after the release of HBP so this review is my liveblog.<br /><br />In no particular order, good things:<br />1. Harry's death scene<br />2. Snape dying at the hands of Voldemort (very appropriate)<br />3. The Dursleys (always good, tbh)<br />4. Draco <br />5. Kreacher, to a degree. It's a nice idea, but it's profoundly unconvincing.<br />6. Remus guessing that the death eaters knew which Harry was Harry Potter as expelliarmus is seen as Harry's signature move. Hilarious. And true. One of the 5 duelling spells he knows. <br /><br />Terrible things<br />1. The epilogue<br />2. The writing. 'All was well.' 'It is I, Remus J Lupin.' Harry regretting that he will never be 'pierced' by Dumbledore's eyes again. Harry describing Voldemort's eye in a locket as 'handsome' (JKR falling over herself to use the same adjectives over and over again to describe Tom vs Voldemort is really irritating....)<br />3. Voldemort's complete lack of menace and dignity. He's soaring around the skies trying to curse Harry? He's also forgotten that Harry can access his mind - in fact, in this book Harry actually reads Voldemort's thoughts which is something he never could do before and is extremely convenient, to say the least. <br />4. The long period of time that Harry, Ron and Hermione run around in improbable scenarios, achieving nothing<br />5. The Ron-Harry fallout - it felt completely pasted in as did its resolution - Voldemort sending Ron visions of Harry and Hermione kissing? Really, it underscored what a pathetic sap Ron is - it didn't feel like him overcoming anything, just like him continuing to be a useless, sad sap. Speaking of which 'All's fair in love and war'? Rolling my eyes. Go away, Ron.<br />6. Ron opening the Chamber of Secrets? It's an old bathroom. If random hissing sounds could open the chamber, it would have happened before now.<br />7. The cheap deaths in this book. I call them cheap because they were just pointless sacrifices to underscore that shit was getting real without actually meaning anything or making sense with that character's plotline - apart from Dobby, really. You look at the deaths and a random Weasley, Tonks, Lupin, Ted Tonks, Madeye, Hedgwig? <br />8. Umbridge's return. So improbable given that she was Fudge's number 2 and no one would want her back & given that her ending in OOTP was actually imo, perfectly resolved.<br />9. The break-in at Gringott's was underwhelming for something that the reader has been anticipating since PS.<br />10. There should have been more dragons. Charlie's whole thing is dragons. Dragons. <br />11. Voldemort's goals make no sense at all. Even for a megalomaniac. Also his obsession with Hogwarts really makes him a pathetic villain.<br />12. The focus on Dumbledore's backstory - last book it was people trying to reconstruct Voldemort's soap opera of a life and in this book it's Dumbledore, and what a waste of time. Also it's so ridiculous that JKR didn't put Dumbledore's affair with Grindelwald in the book. She had the perfect opportunity to plant even a small suspicion of that with Rita Skeeter's book and chose not to. <br />13. Percy's comeback made no sense. Percy is the only Weasley I've ever liked and I wanted him obviously to stop being pro-Ministry, but Aberforth became very deus ex machina.<br />14. Everything about Lupin.<br />15. Snape. Enough said.<br />16. That the SPEW plot culminates in Ron and Hermione kissing instead of anything meaningful.<br />17. That Harry is still mediocre and profoundly uninterested in magic. Why doesn't he get better at it? Why doesn't he learn nonverbal magic? When he was going on about how he wanted to meet Snape - lol, last book you couldn't even get out a curse. Come on.<br />18. That at age 17, Harry still cannot recognize people as being complex individuals. He focuses only on his latest perception of them - i.e. for a bit Dumbledore was the worst because he hung out with an evil wizard for two months, nevermind that he's a gazillion years old; and Snape is redeemed for all his sins by his creepy devotion to Harry's mother despite all the fuckery he's been responsible for during Harry's time at Hogwarts and Voldemort attacking him in the first place. Where is your child named after Sirius?<br />19. I cannot believe that there isn't a respectable and notable contingent of Slytherins fighting against Voldemort because despite being traditionalists with their blood purity mumbo jumbo, they don't want to be ruled by an immortal megalomaniac who kills people on whim. How did that not occur to the Malfoys before their involvement, I mean, really. The idea was floated about in GOF briefly but nothing seems to come of it.<br />20. Because Harry was willing to die for EVERYONE, everyone is protected by his love? But he didn't even think that killing himself would save everyone - there was still corporeal Voldemort and Nagini? Ridiculous. It kind of deflates the notion of parental love as well, which I liked.<br />21. Neville should have killed Bellatrix instead of JKR forcing her good femininity vs bad femininity ideas down our throats once again.<br />22. Voldemort's death was absurd. The Elder Wand stuff? What even. And Harry's speechifying ....</span>  <a data-text-id="4942033597621415293" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review852497588">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link852497588" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=852497588&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/136251.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_852497588'><a id="like_count_review_852497588" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/852497588?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">11 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_852497588" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_852497588" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_203027128" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/203027128" />    <a title="Saoirse Sterling" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4639825-saoirse-sterling"><img alt="Saoirse Sterling" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1478339708p2/4639825.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/203027128?book_show_action=false">Jun 01, 2016</a>      <a title="Saoirse Sterling" class="user" name="Saoirse Sterling" href="/user/show/4639825-saoirse-sterling">Saoirse Sterling</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9781551929767" href="/book/show/818056.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4639825-saoirse-sterling?shelf=intriguing-but-ultimately-naff">intriguing-but-ultimately-naff</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4639825-saoirse-sterling?shelf=sterling">sterling</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4639825-saoirse-sterling?shelf=feminine">feminine</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4639825-saoirse-sterling?shelf=ce21">ce21</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4639825-saoirse-sterling?shelf=bookshelf">bookshelf</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer203027128" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer1459125396199997783">[First read: 2007. 2 stars<br />Second read: 1st March, 2016. 3 stars.]<br /><br />Read as part of the <a target="_blank" href="https://xleptodactylous.blogspot.co.uk/2016/01/infinite-variety-book-challenge-2016.html" rel="nofollow">#InfiniteVariety2016 Reading Challenge</a> based on the BBC's Big Read poll.<br /><br />Here's a big fat review (longer than I usually write, more rambling and less coherent) that will focus on the series as a whole, as well as just this book.<br /><br />The first time I read this book-all those years ago when it first came out-I was pretty much fed up with Harry Potter at that point. It was too big: nothing deserves to be that big, not ev</span>  <span id="freeText1459125396199997783" style="display:none">[First read: 2007. 2 stars<br />Second read: 1st March, 2016. 3 stars.]<br /><br />Read as part of the <a target="_blank" href="https://xleptodactylous.blogspot.co.uk/2016/01/infinite-variety-book-challenge-2016.html" rel="nofollow">#InfiniteVariety2016 Reading Challenge</a> based on the BBC's Big Read poll.<br /><br />Here's a big fat review (longer than I usually write, more rambling and less coherent) that will focus on the series as a whole, as well as just this book.<br /><br />The first time I read this book-all those years ago when it first came out-I was pretty much fed up with Harry Potter at that point. It was too big: nothing deserves to be that big, not even Jesus, and it was, quite frankly, boring. So I skipped through the book and didn't really pay much attention. I also didn't see the film until much, much later and as a whole, the big pile of fandom just passed me by in to the void of nothingness behind me.<br /><br />As the years passed by, I wanted to dip my toe back in. I was feeling a bit nostalgic, I admit, but I also wanted to see if the magic of Harry Potter that everyone was going on about was there for me, too. TLDR; it is not.<br /><br />This book, the final of the series, is definitely one of the best of the series but it has some serious faults. You can definitely see the pressure that J.K. was under from, oh look, you lot, to finish the book and get it out so they could make the next film. I don't think this was quite the ending she really wanted and that is quite a big disappointment, though we can't hold the author accountable. (It's all your fault, really.)<br /><br />We still have two protagonists who haven't changed much in seven years: Harry and Ron have been the same semi-intelligent, slightly amusing and stupidly brave boys that we met in the first book. Hermione, I am glad to say, has changed from book to book, though there were a few moments when she really went a bit dodgy. As far as the other characters, I have to say they were all pretty much background and dull. I still can't get over how Luna Lovegood just turns up and randomly becomes an important character without actually saying or doing much at all. I also think a lot more could have been done with Neville: I thought he was pretty great and the way he ended the series was wonderful. It's very difficult to enjoy a series of books when you don't like (not hate) the main character. Did anyone really care if Harry died at the end, as long as Voldemort did as well? I didn't.<br /><br />I was also not a fan of the way most of the unpleasant characters were either fat or ugly. Most of the weird characters were a bit odd-looking, as well, and it just felt like an easy get-out of having to think of interesting characters who didn't conform to type. <br /><br />The thing about fantasy is that it's usually mostly the locations and settings that really make it magical. <i>Harry Potter</i> is extremely limited in location and that really made it feel small and closed off. Yes, Hogwarts is a fun Scottish castle, but really how much do we know about Hogwarts; how much did we really see? We barely explore the place and the places around it. I understand that magical people are pretty much hidden away, but it always felt like such a lacking world. Hogwarts was no more magical than Harry's cupboard, really (enchanted ceiling notwithstanding).<br /><br /><i>The Deathly Hallows</i> never quite felt like the ending it should have been. It was definitely the best written of the set, which just shows how a writer learns from their previous mistakes (which, sadly, a lot of authors don't seem to do) and the flow from preceding book to the follow up was better than it had been earlier on.<br /><br />I can't really see myself ever reading these ever again, unless I really run out of things to read. I find that rather saddening, because I can remember a time in my childhood-during the first few years of the earlier books and films-when I really loved this series. I remember the two weeks I really wanted to be an actor so I could be in the film and elope with whoever it was that played Sirius (Gary Oldman, I know, but back then I didn't care). I strongly remember that I felt bad for being in love with Draco for about a year, too (I have a thing for blondes). I will look back fondly on my mis-remembered feelings on Luna and treasure my rekindled love for Hermione. I think I am incredibly lucky to be of an age where I grew up at the right time for this series, but I'm also not supremely disappointed that the magic is no longer there.</span>  <a data-text-id="1459125396199997783" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review203027128">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link203027128" class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_203027128'><a id="like_count_review_203027128" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/203027128?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">11 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_203027128" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_203027128" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=11&rating[page]=7&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=203027128&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/203027128?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=7">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_203027128' style='display: none;'></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_47633677" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/47633677" />    <a title="Sassymelody" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/2070442-sassymelody"><img alt="Sassymelody" src="https://s.gr-assets.com/assets/nophoto/user/u_5f-632230dc9882b4352d753eedf9396530.png" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/47633677?book_show_action=false">Jun 02, 2009</a>      <a title="Sassymelody" class="user" name="Sassymelody" href="/user/show/2070442-sassymelody">Sassymelody</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">did not like it</span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">                  <em>                    This review has been hidden because it contains spoilers. To view it,                    <a href="#" onclick="Effect.toggle(&#39;reviewTextContainer47633677&#39;); return false;">click here.</a>                  </em>              <span id="reviewTextContainer47633677" class="readable"                    style="display:none"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10056737718504943040">Can you give a novel no stars? Have you ever had a book or certain kind of music that encapsulated your childhood? That was the Harry Potter series. Sure I read far better books, but it was fun and novel, something I could share with a wider group of friends. And I loved the first books...then I started to feel as though we would have been better off if the fanfic authors we in charge; at least we'd have some canon then. I mean honestly woman, you spend all this time telling us how wonderful</span>  <span id="freeText10056737718504943040" style="display:none">Can you give a novel no stars? Have you ever had a book or certain kind of music that encapsulated your childhood? That was the Harry Potter series. Sure I read far better books, but it was fun and novel, something I could share with a wider group of friends. And I loved the first books...then I started to feel as though we would have been better off if the fanfic authors we in charge; at least we'd have some canon then. I mean honestly woman, you spend all this time telling us how wonderful James and his friends are, that they were such great, heroic people and you make the Marauders (who in some ways are more loved than the Trio) into a group of utter assholes. I couldn't find the redeeming qualities. And Lily! We spend six bloody book listening to "You have your mother's eye." and promises that Lily will play an important role in the story, then when all is said and done it's because Snape was lusting after her! That's the fucking reason? She dropped the ball here. <br /><br />Tonks was never more than a flat, uninteresting piece of wallpaper. Lupin was unrealistic given the character building you'd done in the other novels. Ginny could have actually had a real role, contributed in some way! Hermione was reduced to a walking 'Hogwarts, A History'. Ron, was, well Ron, useless, immature and pathetic. At least Harry stopped being a whiny, angst-filled 14-year-old GIRL. The list goes on and on.<br /><br />Alright, I am now forced to say something I never thought I would say. The slash (male/male shippers) actually have a point. Remus and Sirius in a relationship makes far more sense than Remus and Tonks. The undercurrents are there and least he was a moderately developed (and promising to be so much more if it hadn't been for the damned drapery) character as opposed to furniture. <br /><br />And what the hell, fucking Dobby was the most poignant death in the entire damn novel. This is so wrong. There is so much depth and emotion there for a secondary character, who for many fans was the HP version of Jar Jar Binks. He gets an entire scene whereas Remus, who is Harry's last tie to his parents, and Tonks get one sentence, a side note in a paragraph.<br /><br />It was predictable and nowhere near as good as it could have been. JKR has talent. There are moments that are just beautiful, and she has created a wonderfully descriptive world. However I don't think she had the chops to sustain it. We could see that in earlier books where instead of showing the action she fell back on "Harry wakes up in the hospital wing and everything is explained to him." Battles and epic quests aren't her strong point. <br /><br />It is sad when your epilogue reads like a bad piece of fanfiction. It's also sad when it seems like fanfic authors could have done a better job writing your story, when they would have stayed more in canon.<br /><br />I will give her this, I loved Neville in this book. He deserved all the screen time he got and more. There has been so much character development for him since the start of the series. However, and this is both a kudos and a critic, the most character development in the story went to the Malfoy family. They went from foil evil characters/villains to real people whose main concern was for their family. The scene where Narcissa and Lucius ignore the battle and are desperately trying to find Draco was spectacular. <br /><br />This could have been a great book, hell it could have at least been good. Instead it is something fans will read because they loved the series. There is so much more to say, but I think I'll cut it short here.<br /><br /><br /></span>  <a data-text-id="10056737718504943040" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review47633677">  <td colspan="2">    <div id='like_container_review_47633677'><a id="like_count_review_47633677" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/47633677?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">11 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_47633677" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_47633677" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=11&rating[page]=7&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=47633677&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_47633677" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 47633677, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">comment</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/47633677?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=7">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_47633677' style='display: none;'></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_47633677' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 47633677, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_102098986" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/102098986" />    <a title="Melissa Jackson" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/2314907-melissa-jackson"><img alt="Melissa Jackson" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1443107039p2/2314907.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/102098986?book_show_action=false">Jun 27, 2011</a>      <a title="Melissa Jackson" class="user" name="Melissa Jackson" href="/user/show/2314907-melissa-jackson">Melissa Jackson</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer102098986" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer14129113042032912989">I finally finished the Harry Potter series. I guess I shouldn't say finally-- when I bemoaned how long it took me to read the 7 book series (2 months), people reacted with incredulous remarks of how that was not a long time to take. I guess it just felt like it. I loved the books so much, always wanted to read them (I liked them the way you do when a book is just delicious. You think about it when you can't read it and nothing brings you more satisfaction than to finally unlatch your brain and</span>  <span id="freeText14129113042032912989" style="display:none">I finally finished the Harry Potter series. I guess I shouldn't say finally-- when I bemoaned how long it took me to read the 7 book series (2 months), people reacted with incredulous remarks of how that was not a long time to take. I guess it just felt like it. I loved the books so much, always wanted to read them (I liked them the way you do when a book is just delicious. You think about it when you can't read it and nothing brings you more satisfaction than to finally unlatch your brain and crawl in the story at the end of the day...sigh. Is this just me? It can't be.), and considering how easy the first several books in the series were, it just felt like forever. A measly nothing compared to some friends of mine who, from H.P. onset, had to wait a year between each book. Sometimes more-- one friend took 8 years to complete the series due to the epidemic we Bibliophile's refer to as "release waiting".<br /><br />I loved this book best of all. It showed Harry's dark and light, with more balance than the previous books. Harry was what you wanted and expected him to be. A friend whose personality you knew well and could predict. That was the other fun part of Deathly Hallows, being able to predict with authority different mysteries along the way, just from your absorption in each character and the different spells and places and names that seemed alive-- you know your magic if you've made it this far. JKR is brilliant. Absolutely brilliant. Every little detail is important. Everything. In a way that leaves no stone unturned, but not in a irritating fashion. It's concise. It grabs you and it feels real.<br /><br />The last 100 pages were almost agonizing in their emotional force. The book was immediately on a whole different level than all the editions before. I am talking 2nd. page into the book, it was darker and more intense-- a higher level of writing, a deeper level of what you knew was coming from the beginning. A terrible cost. Even JKR's vocabulary choices. It's elevated and therefor all the more impacting. Voldemort comes into his full stride, completing his ultimate symbolism of the dark side of man and the spirit, and it is terrifying. These characters that you feel you know are in life or death situations for over 700 pages. It's utterly gripping.<br /><br />I felt like I had said goodbye to an old friend at the end. That's always a good thing for a reader.<br /><br />Yeah, it's a young adult story. Clearly. But it has a wonderful message and unbelievably inspiring characters and situations that teach lessons that all ages could do well to heed.<br /><br />I treasure my books. If you've been to my house, you know this. If you went in my room as a kid or teenager, you'd know this. My life has been surrounded with books. Rarely loaned and often cleaned, they fill my home. I have Harry Potter sitting beneath my fireplace, in the center of my living room. Just to make sure I can keep an eye on them.<br /><br />"Would I?" asked Dumbledore heavily. "I am not so sure. I had proven, as a very young man, that power was my weakness and my temptation. It is a curious thing, Harry, but perhaps those who are best suited to power are those who have never sought it. Those who, like you, have leadership thrust upon them, and take up the mantle because they must, and find their own surprise that they wear it well."</span>  <a data-text-id="14129113042032912989" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review102098986">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link102098986" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=102098986&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/136251.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_102098986'><a id="like_count_review_102098986" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/102098986?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">11 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_102098986" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_102098986" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button comments</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/102098986?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=7">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_102098986' style='display:  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1304972074" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1304972074" />    <a title="Kirsty (Amethyst Bookwyrm)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/7436809-kirsty-amethyst-bookwyrm"><img alt="Kirsty (Amethyst Bookwyrm)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1364999103p2/7436809.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1304972074?book_show_action=false">Jul 03, 2015</a>      <a title="Kirsty (Amethyst Bookwyrm)" class="user" name="Kirsty (Amethyst Bookwyrm)" href="/user/show/7436809-kirsty-amethyst-bookwyrm">Kirsty (Amethyst Bookwyrm)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780747591054" href="/book/show/820343.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/7436809-kirsty-amethyst-bookwyrm?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/7436809-kirsty-amethyst-bookwyrm?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/7436809-kirsty-amethyst-bookwyrm?shelf=review">review</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1304972074" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5923474930316974606">Warning, this review has spoilers for this book and the entire series.<br /><br />Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is the final brilliant book in the Harry Potter series and it answers all the question raised in the previous books but still leaves us wanting more. This is different from all the other books as the war has been lost and Hogwarts is not the main setting of the story. While this is the most adult book in the series, the series does still feel innocent especially as the characters do not thi</span>  <span id="freeText5923474930316974606" style="display:none">Warning, this review has spoilers for this book and the entire series.<br /><br />Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is the final brilliant book in the Harry Potter series and it answers all the question raised in the previous books but still leaves us wanting more. This is different from all the other books as the war has been lost and Hogwarts is not the main setting of the story. While this is the most adult book in the series, the series does still feel innocent especially as the characters do not think like most teenagers. <br /><br />These books have all been about how love triumphs all and that death is not the end but the beginning of a new story. Unfortunately, it was obvious that the Deathly Hallows were added just to this book as there was no references to them in previous books unlike the Horcruxes. One thing I have never liked in this series is the labelling of Slytherin students as evil, as just because they are cunning and ambitious does not mean they will all turn into Death Eaters. Is it bad that I was more upset over Hedwig dying than MoodyU+2019s death?<br /><br />I always felt that Harry should have died at the end of this series for two reasons, firstly then Rowling would not have been pressured to write more in the series, and secondly it felt like HarryU+2019s entire life was destined to stopping Voldemort and, like Frodo in The Lord of the Rings, I am not sure he would have been able to move and carry on with his life without a purpose. I also really liked NevilleU+2019s development over the series as he has gained confidence and has become the person he was meant to be.<br /><br />I love Ron and HermioneU+2019s relationship and when I first read this book when I was younger, I was hoping that they would end up together but now I feel that with the amount of time they spent together without acting on their feelings they would have been stuck in the friend zone. Snape is one of the most interesting and complex characters and I loved learning more about his past. I also liked hearing about DumbledoreU+2019s darker past which I feels humanises him. I guessed what was going to happen to Lupin and Tonks in this book after Harry was named Godfather, as I could tell that TedU+2019s situation would mirror HarryU+2019s. <br /><br />When I first read this series I thought the ending would have been about Hogwarts and maybe Harry and VoldemortU+2019s links to the houses or that Neville was actually the chosen one. After I finished this book when it originally came out I felt like my childhood had ended as I had grown up with these characters and even now 8 years later I also got the same feeling. I would recommend the entire Harry Potter series to everyone, even those who have watched the films as they donU+2019t have the magic of the books. <br />All was well. <br /><br />This and my other reviews can be found at <a href="http://amethystbookwyrm.blogspot.co.uk/" rel="nofollow">Amethyst Bookwyrm</a><br /></span>  <a data-text-id="5923474930316974606" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/661194723?book_show_action=false">Feb 28, 2014</a>      <a title="Erica Ravenclaw" class="user" name="Erica Ravenclaw" href="/user/show/12099580-erica-ravenclaw">Erica Ravenclaw</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer661194723" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer8754005774654474344"><br><br><br><b> No Spoilers! </b><br><br>August 1st 2007 I was 22 years old and finishing up my summer courses so I could graduate early. I had recently broken up with a long term boyfriend, was living with roommates, and was on the verge of throwing out everything I owned and taking my dog and my backpack on an adventure. I was on the cusp of a great change, one I somewhat understood and equally couldn't begin to understand. It is only now that many years has past that I can see that was when I chose my path on the kind</span>  <span id="freeText8754005774654474344" style="display:none"><br>U+2606 U+2606 U+2606 U+2606 U+2606<br><br><b> No Spoilers! </b><br><br>August 1st 2007 I was 22 years old and finishing up my summer courses so I could graduate early. I had recently broken up with a long term boyfriend, was living with roommates, and was on the verge of throwing out everything I owned and taking my dog and my backpack on an adventure. I was on the cusp of a great change, one I somewhat understood and equally couldn't begin to understand. It is only now that many years has past that I can see that was when I chose my path on the kind of life I wanted to lead: one based on fear or one motivated by a challenge. I have a distinct memory of being absolutely wrecked when I read this the first time and I reread it immediately after I finished. There was something about Neville's journey most of all that spoke to me and was reflected in my life at the time but I struggled putting it all together. <br><br>It is only now that I have reread this series in it's entirety as an adult that it became clear. We are a sum of our choices. No matter what events unfold in our journey ultimately we are in charge of the outcome, to be true to our moral fiber, and to continue to live an inspired life on your terms. I'm not going to talk about this book, there is nothing I can say that has not been said a thousand times over. I will simply suggest that if you find yourself on the cusp of a great change and are hesitant to take the next steps, please remember:<br><a href="http://s1212.photobucket.com/user/PetiteAme/media/Halloween Upload/GIFS/49873588e4a21f77494e9f46c892e150_zpsc0879c34.jpg.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">  <img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1393600370i/8737793._SY540_.jpg" alt=" photo 49873588e4a21f77494e9f46c892e150_zpsc0879c34.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a></span>  <a data-text-id="8754005774654474344" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div href="/user/show/50716395-tara"><img alt="Tara" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1473778194p2/50716395.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1608751793?book_show_action=false">Apr 16, 2016</a>      <a title="Tara" class="user" name="Tara" href="/user/show/50716395-tara">Tara</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1608751793" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9846458842496362809">Giving it 5 stars even though I cried like an absolute baby through the whole second half of this book. Gone are so many amazing characters that I loved so much.. <br /><br />I feel as though a giant Hogwarts-shaped hole has been left in my heart by completing this series. It was a ride I started in January, and what a ride it was! This world is unlike anything I've ever read about before, and I am going to miss it so much (though of course I'll revisit it as often as I can!).<br /><br />The characters are going to sti</span>  <span id="freeText9846458842496362809" style="display:none">Giving it 5 stars even though I cried like an absolute baby through the whole second half of this book. Gone are so many amazing characters that I loved so much.. <br /><br />I feel as though a giant Hogwarts-shaped hole has been left in my heart by completing this series. It was a ride I started in January, and what a ride it was! This world is unlike anything I've ever read about before, and I am going to miss it so much (though of course I'll revisit it as often as I can!).<br /><br />The characters are going to stick with me for a long time as well, their bravery and humor and wisdom and, in some cases, their sacrifice.. I feel as though I've lost dear friends, and I shed many tears as I finished their story. <br /><br />But that's the joy of a book; these friends can be visited again and again! I hope to watch all of the movies soon, too, and to visit Orlando so I can see Hogwarts up on the hill, and Hogsmeade and Diagon Alley..<br /><br />Thank you, JK, for this amazing journey. I was a little late to the party, but better late than never!</span>  <a data-text-id="9846458842496362809" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span> elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_604244940" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/604244940" />    <a title="Gitte Winneche" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/18428309-gitte-winneche"><img alt="Gitte Winneche" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1477550297p2/18428309.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/604244940?book_show_action=false">Apr 15, 2015</a>      <a title="Gitte Winneche" class="user" name="Gitte Winneche" href="/user/show/18428309-gitte-winneche">Gitte Winneche</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780747591054" href="/book/show/820343.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/18428309-gitte-winneche?shelf=own-and-read">own-and-read</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/18428309-gitte-winneche?shelf=own">own</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer604244940" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17606772451336280671">I have been crying, no, sobbing for at least the last sixty pages. My face is swollen and my heart is aching. Even though this must be near my 15th reread of the series, I simply cannot avoid feeling the same sense of awe and wonder and utter devotion as the very first time I had to face the last pages of a world, in which I had become so entangled. To close this book, to stroke its back cover, will for ever more be an action of both utterly and entire admiration and bitter sweet remorse that it</span>  <span id="freeText17606772451336280671" style="display:none">I have been crying, no, sobbing for at least the last sixty pages. My face is swollen and my heart is aching. Even though this must be near my 15th reread of the series, I simply cannot avoid feeling the same sense of awe and wonder and utter devotion as the very first time I had to face the last pages of a world, in which I had become so entangled. To close this book, to stroke its back cover, will for ever more be an action of both utterly and entire admiration and bitter sweet remorse that it has all ended. I can do nothing but let myself reread these words of wonder and wisdom again and again and allow myself to be swept of my feet repeatedly, allow myself to be overwhelmed by all these feelings that I have never ever encountered in any other book in all my life. No book as the Harry Potter series affects me this thoroughly, and I expect - with both joy and regret - that none ever will.</span>  <a data-text-id="17606772451336280671" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id='like_container_review_604244940'><a id="like_count_review_604244940" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/604244940?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">11 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_604244940" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_604244940" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button       </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1564304429" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer269769565179452964"><b> <i>U+201CYou'll stay with me? U+2018Until the very end,' said James.U+201D</i> </b><br><br>So I have finally read all of the Harry Potter books and I feel accomplished (most of them anyways since Cursed Child is coming. WhoU+2019s excited? I definitely am!!). I have been meaning to read these for a while since I became a fan of the movies but sometimes life get in the way, you know, but I finally did it :D<br><br>I can say this with 100% sureness, that this is my all-time favourite because it was just simply FANTASTIC. I loved that this boo</span>  <span id="freeText269769565179452964" style="display:none"><b>  <i>U+201CYou'll stay with me? U+2018Until the very end,' said James.U+201D</i></b><br><br>So I have finally read all of the Harry Potter books and I feel accomplished (most of them anyways since Cursed Child is coming. WhoU+2019s excited? I definitely am!!). I have been meaning to read these for a while since I became a fan of the movies but sometimes life get in the way, you know, but I finally did it :D<br><br>I can say this with 100% sureness, that this is my all-time favourite because it was just simply FANTASTIC. I loved that this book was much better than the movies causeU+2019 the movies just lacked, to be honest. <br><br>I would like to thank J.k Rowling for creating a wonderful world of magic with characters that develop in their own way for the better and I will forever cherish these characters in my heart. They are the best! <br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1457685211ra/18387159.gif" width="550" height="250" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></span>  <a <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/207711197?book_show_action=false">Aug 29, 2012</a>      <a title="Inge" class="user" name="Inge" href="/user/show/6278820-inge">Inge</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9781551929767" href="/book/show/818056.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6278820-inge?shelf=laugh-out-loud-funny">laugh-out-loud-funny</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite"  <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6278820-inge?shelf=main-character-is-cool">main-character-is-cool</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6278820-inge?shelf=magic">magic</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6278820-inge?shelf=all-time-favourites">all-time-favourites</a>,               <a href="/review/list/6278820-inge?shelf=emotional">emotional</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6278820-inge?shelf=smiles-a-plenty">smiles-a-plenty</a>,               <a href="/review/list/6278820-inge?shelf=children">children</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6278820-inge?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer207711197" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10832384620706622753">It is time to put aside the Harry Potter series for a while and move on again, only to come back to it in a while to re-read it once more. I could never do these books justice by writing a review. What these books mean to so many people couldn't possibly be put into words. It has, once again, been an emotional rollercoaster filled with magic, mystery, moments and more. I feel honoured that I get to be a part of HarryU+2019s life and live with him as he makes friends, loves and solves the big puzzle</span>  <span id="freeText10832384620706622753" style="display:none">It is time to put aside the Harry Potter series for a while and move on again, only to come back to it in a while to re-read it once more. I could never do these books justice by writing a review. What these books mean to so many people couldn't possibly be put into words. It has, once again, been an emotional rollercoaster filled with magic, mystery, moments and more. I feel honoured that I get to be a part of HarryU+2019s life and live with him as he makes friends, loves and solves the big puzzle that is Lord Voldemort. The books take me away from reality, to a better, magical place and make me forget about all my problems. For that, I will <i>always</i> be grateful. <b>Thank you, J.K. Rowling.</b><br><br>I will forever be waiting for my Hogwarts acceptance letter.<br><br><a href="http://tinypic.com?ref=f1iely" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">  <img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1380358779i/709956.jpg" alt="Image and video hosting by TinyPic" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a></span>  <a
