</div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1356129338" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1356129338" />    <a title="Josen" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/3660423-josen"><img alt="Josen" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1451696073p2/3660423.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1356129338?book_show_action=false">Feb 16, 2016</a>      <a title="Josen" class="user" name="Josen" href="/user/show/3660423-josen">Josen</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Audio CD 9780739360415" href="/book/show/1522943.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3660423-josen?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3660423-josen?shelf=2016-library">2016-library</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3660423-josen?shelf=audio">audio</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1356129338" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer12328325044239891531">Siiiggghh........where do I begin? As many people already know, this is a great, great series! Yes I was on the late train reading these and I'm not even sure why I had put them off in the first place. My daughter had been a huge fan of course, so a few years ago we did the trip to the Orlando Harry Potter at Universal and even though I only knew the gist of the stories at that time (and watched a few movies) I instantly felt transported into that world and loved it. -----Now after having read</span>  <span id="freeText12328325044239891531" style="display:none">Siiiggghh........where do I begin? As many people already know, this is a great, great series! Yes I was on the late train reading these and I'm not even sure why I had put them off in the first place. My daughter had been a huge fan of course, so a few years ago we did the trip to the Orlando Harry Potter at Universal and even though I only knew the gist of the stories at that time (and watched a few movies) I instantly felt transported into that world and loved it. -----Now after having read (or listened to) the books I am an utter and complete Harry Potter fan. :) Right before I finished this last book, I was on vacation and did a Harry Potter movie marathon, which I still thought they did a great job even though they of course couldn't catch every single detail in the books. When I finished the movies I felt at a kind of loss because it was over but I knew I still had the books to finish so there was still that last bit of attachment. Now..........the books are done.............and I don't know what to do. Lol! You get so attached to the books it's like raising a child and then having them go off on their own. :( <br /><br />I now have a new found respect for J.K. Rowling. The love for the characters, the wizarding world, the detail in each story...........not enough words to say how great these books were. I'm really not the type to reread books, but since I listened to these I think I will reread the actual books at some point. Because I don't think you can have too much time pass without SOME bit of Harry Potter in your life. :)</span>  <a data-text-id="12328325044239891531" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1356129338">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1356129338" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1356129338&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/136251.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1356129338'><a id="like_count_review_1356129338" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1356129338?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">8 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1356129338" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1356129338" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=8&rating[page]=9&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=1356129338&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_1356129338" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 1356129338, true, &#39;&#39;); class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer2388264355108692189">Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is the last book of Harry Potter! (Or at least for now) In this book, the saga finally comes to its highest climax, where the super famous magician must face the final battle against Lord Voldemort. Although I'm a big fan of Harry Potter, as a writer I was somewhat disappointed with its ending, specially with the last chapter. I got the feeling that J. K. Rowling (whether by the pressure from her fans or her own editors) didn't give an overwhelming and</span>  <span id="freeText2388264355108692189" style="display:none">Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is the last book of Harry Potter! (Or at least for now) In this book, the saga finally comes to its highest climax, where the super famous magician must face the final battle against Lord Voldemort. Although I'm a big fan of Harry Potter, as a writer I was somewhat disappointed with its ending, specially with the last chapter. I got the feeling that J. K. Rowling (whether by the pressure from her fans or her own editors) didn't give an overwhelming and emotional ending to the wonderful saga. I won't tell you my own ending idea, but I guess all who have read that will know what I mean! ;)<br /><br />Spanish version: <br />Harry Potter y las RelU+00EDquias de la Muerte es el U+00FAltimo de los libros de Harry Potter! (O al menos por ahora) En este libro la saga de siete libros por fin llega a su mU+00E1ximo clU+00EDmax en el que el archifamoso mago deberU+00E1 luchar a vida o muerte contra el enemigo del mundo mU+00E1gico Lord Voldemort. Aunque soy un gran fan de Harry Potter, como escritor me sentU+00ED algo decepcionado con su final. Me dio la sensaciU+00F3n que J. K. Rowling (ya fuese por presiones de los fans o de sus propios editores) no se atreviU+00F3 a dar un final contundente a la maravillosa saga. No os contarU+00E9 mi idea de final pero supongo que todos los que lo habU+00E9is leU+00EDdo sabrU+00E9is a lo que me refiero! ;)<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="2388264355108692189" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1726157176" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer625290568653671903">Bu sadece bir son deU+011Fildi, sadece bir serinin sonu deU+011Fildi. Bir dU+00FCnyanU+0131n sonuydu. Beni kitaplara baU+011Flayan, okumayU+0131 sevdiren serinin sonu. Ve bu kitap mU+00FC-kem-mel-di. <br />Joanne her satU+0131rU+0131nda duygularU+0131 o kadar gU+00FCzel belli etmiU+015F ki her seferinde kitabU+0131n iU+00E7inde o olaylarU+0131 ben de yaU+015F U+0131yormuU+015Fum, ben de tanU+0131k oluyormuU+015Fum gibi geldi. Dumbledore'un sU+00F6zlerinden, Snape'in anU+0131larU+0131ndan, Tom Riddle'U+0131n hortkuluklarU+0131ndan, nereden bakarsanU+0131z bakU+0131n bu kitap kusursuz bir kurguyla yazU+0131lmU+0131 U+015F. <br />En azU+0131ndan ben bu seriyi okud</span>  <span id="freeText625290568653671903" style="display:none">Bu sadece bir son deU+011Fildi, sadece bir serinin sonu deU+011Fildi. Dumbledore'un sU+00F6zlerinden, Snape'in anU+0131larU+0131ndan, Tom Riddle'U+0131n hortkuluklarU+0131ndan, nereden bakarsanU+0131z bakU+0131n bu kitap kusursuz bir kurguyla yazU+0131lmU+0131 U+015F. <br />En azU+0131ndan ben bu seriyi okuduU+011Fum iU+00E7in kendimi U+00E7ok U+015FanslU+0131 hissediyorum. Elimin altU+0131nda kitaplarU+0131n olmasU+0131 da beni U+015FanslU+0131 hissettiriyor. Bu seri bitmiU+015F olabilir ama Joanne Rowling'in dediU+011Fi gibi; ''Ne zaman kitaplarU+0131nU+0131zU+0131n sayfalarU+0131nU+0131 aU+00E7sanU+0131z ya da ekranlarU+0131nU+0131zU+0131n baU+015F itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/813050535?book_show_action=false">Jan 17, 2016</a>      <a title="Suna" class="user" name="Suna" href="/user/show/27364894-suna">Suna</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9780545583008" href="/book/show/17347379-harry-potter-and-the-deathly-hallows">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/27364894-suna?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer813050535" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer8620346696479957342">It's so hard to believe I've finished the series already. Being honest, I read the whole HP series this year. I've only read the third and seventh book ages ago. I have to say that this is definitely one of my favorite series of all times and I'm sure that I'll reread the series in the future. I had so much fun following the characters throughout their journey. I've been a huge fan of the movies, but after reading the books I realized how much I was really missing out by not reading the books.</span>  <span id="freeText8620346696479957342" style="display:none">It's so hard to believe I've finished the series already. Being honest, I read the whole HP series this year. I've only read the third and seventh book ages ago. I have to say that this is definitely one of my favorite series of all times and I'm sure that I'll reread the series in the future. I had so much fun following the characters throughout their journey. I've been a huge fan of the movies, but after reading the books I realized how much I was really missing out by not reading the books. I'm so glad I bought the pretty boxset and read the whole series. I don't think I can really put into words how much I really loved this series.</span>  <a data-text-id="8620346696479957342" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a> id="reviewTextContainer1253980611" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9959615110018191931">I probably should have read this series years ago but OH MY GOD, I DO NOT CARE BECAUSE I HAVE NOW FINISHED IT AND IT WAS SO AMAZING. <br /><br />I've never read a book that can both warm and break your heart at the same time, like this one did. Yeah, I don't really know what to say. It's kind of hard to think about it without crying. <br /><br /><i>U+201CIt's going to be all right, sir," Harry said over and over again, more worried by Dumbledore's silence than he had been by his weakened voice. "We're nearly there ... I can Ap</i></span>  <span id="freeText9959615110018191931" style="display:none">I probably should have read this series years ago but OH MY GOD, I DO NOT CARE BECAUSE I HAVE NOW FINISHED IT AND IT WAS SO AMAZING. <br /><br />I've never read a book that can both warm and break your heart at the same time, like this one did. Yeah, I don't really know what to say. It's kind of hard to think about it without crying. <br /><br /><i>U+201CIt's going to be all right, sir," Harry said over and over again, more worried by Dumbledore's silence than he had been by his weakened voice. "We're nearly there ... I can Apparate us both back ... don't worry ..."<br />"I am not worried, Harry," said Dumbledore, his voice a little stronger despite the freezing water. </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1075197251" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer14098173381854965184">I don't think that it's an exaggeration to say that this series is what has been missing from my life. Reading the Harry Potter books was a wild journey. My only wish is that I had this sooner. That I could've read it as a child. I know I would've loved it. I believe that these book are fantastical and even life-changing.</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1474860917p2/3423386.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1366941339?book_show_action=false">Aug 19, 2015</a>      <a title="Kristine" class="user" name="Kristine" href="/user/show/3423386-kristine">Kristine</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar id="reviewTextContainer1366941339" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5253436807934589196">U+03A3 U+03B1 U+03B3 U+03CC U+03BD U+03B9 U+03C3 U+03C4 U+03BF U+03C0 U+03BB U+03CD U+03C4 U+03B5 U+03C1 U+03B5 U+03C2 U+03B4 U+03B9 U+03B1 U+03BA U+03BF U+03C0 U+03AD U+03C2 U+03C0 U+03BF U+03C5 U+03AD U+03BA U+03B1 U+03BD U+03B1 U+03C0 U+03BF U+03C4 U+03AD.</span> class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1366941339" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." id='like_container_review_1366941339'><a id="like_count_review_1366941339" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1366941339?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">8 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1366941339" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1366941339" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=8&rating[page]=10&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=1366941339&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_1366941339" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 1366941339, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">comment</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/1366941339?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=10">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1366941339' style='display: none;'></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1366941339' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 1366941339, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_236521537" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/236521537" />    <a title="U+03A0 U+03AD U+03C4 U+03C1 U+03BF U+03C2" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/6984857"><img alt="U+03A0 U+03AD U+03C4 U+03C1 U+03BF U+03C2" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1321523871p2/6984857.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/236521537?book_show_action=false">Nov 18, 2015</a>      <a title="U+03A0 U+03AD U+03C4 U+03C1 U+03BF U+03C2" class="user" name="U+03A0 U+03AD U+03C4 U+03C1 U+03BF U+03C2" href="/user/show/6984857">U+03A0 U+03AD U+03C4 U+03C1 U+03BF U+03C2</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer236521537" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15527524303689071825">Evil gets away unpunished<br />And thus Rowling tries to wrap up this clusterfuck of a story by making everything even more absurd. Starting with HarryU+2019s foster parents who are sent to safety. After all these books they remained the same one dimensional evil idiots and they are now simply removed from the story without changing their minds or being punished for everything they did. All Rowling did was having someone scolding them for being bad caretakers, while they are not saying a word in defense. S</span>  <span id="freeText15527524303689071825" style="display:none">Evil gets away unpunished<br />And thus Rowling tries to wrap up this clusterfuck of a story by making everything even more absurd. Starting with HarryU+2019s foster parents who are sent to safety. After all these books they remained the same one dimensional evil idiots and they are now simply removed from the story without changing their minds or being punished for everything they did. All Rowling did was having someone scolding them for being bad caretakers, while they are not saying a word in defense. Such wonderful characterization Rowling; I totally believe these are real people. Their son said thanks to Harry but only because he had saved his life. Anyone would have done that; thanking someone doesnU+2019t count as character development, and the reason he was attacked by a fiend was not the result of him being a stupid bully. Meaning, the child molesters and the school bullies escaped and lived happily ever after; justice prevailed children.<br /><br />Too many fakes<br />And if you think that didnU+2019t make any sense, get ready to find out how 90% of this book was a wild goose chase. Rowling had no idea of how she could fill 800 pages and just stuffed the story with impersonators and imitations of the items everybody was looking for. This did not make things more exciting; it only wasted hundreds upon hundreds of pages by going in circles, and making the plot even more convoluted than it already was.<br /><br />1) Harry transforms into a ginger kid and many others to Harry look-alikes in order to confuse the villains of who is the real one. He then transforms into a wizard working in the ministry so he can infiltrate the building. And then he gets captured by the villains making this whole plan pointless. He might as well have been captured right away.<br /><br />2) There was a pendant which was switched with a fake one, hidden in a house, where it was eventually found by the villains. You are practically reading a hundred pages of a complicating plan that had zero story progress; there was no point to even go after it in the previous book, only to find out it was fake.<br /><br />3) Harry needs to destroy the pendant by using the sword from the second book. But guess what, the sword which is kept in a treasury is fake. The real one is hidden somewhere else, so we spend hundreds of pages in solving riddles (which could very well be interpreted in any way you like) until they find the sword in the middle of a forest. Once that is done, it is revealed that there a chalice which they also need to destroy. And do you know where that is? In the treasury, right next to the fake sword! They needed to go there regardless.<br /><br />4) I am not even done yet; it gets even more convoluted. Even when Harry gets to the treasury, he doesnU+2019t even get to use the sword. It gets destroyed thus making the quest pointless.<br /><br />5) I am not even done yet; it gets even more convoluted. As soon as he loses the sword, it is revealed that he could have simply used the teeth of the Basilisk he killed in the second book, something which was much easier to find than the sword, rendering once again the quest for the sword completely pointless. And wait a second; if the teeth are so powerful, why didnU+2019t Dumbledore or anyone else take its teeth all these years? This entire quest could have been skipped if Rowling hadnU+2019t forgotten the chamber up until now.<br /><br />6) I am not even done yet; it gets even more convoluted. Another item Harry needs to destroy is a tiara, located inside a secret room which of course none of the adults could find. He gets the teeth, goes there to destroy it, and turns out he didnU+2019t need the teeth or the sword because there is a spell that can destroy the items just as easily, making both quests meaningless. Best part is that the one who used said spell to destroy the tiara, was an ally of Voltemort.<br /><br />7) I am not even done yet; it gets even more convoluted. The only excuse for Harry to know where the tiara is located, is by vaguely remembering he saw it in an area with millions of other stored items. Yeah, such great evidence; totally excuses why you can pinpoint exactly where it is, in a huge room, by casually looking at something, for a few seconds, without being aware of its importance. Great writing Rowling.<br /><br />8) I am not even done yet; it gets even more convoluted. The allies of Voltemort were waiting to ambush Harry by staying in that secret room for months. How did they know he will go there? Why didnU+2019t they simply take the tiara to a safer place first? Why did they use a spell that can destroy it? Why didnU+2019t anyone else find them all this time? How could they even be there if the place was refusing entrance to the supporters of Voltemort? If they found the room before the other teenagers used it as their base and made it Voltemort proof, why didnU+2019t they inform the evil wizards about it, when they knew about it for over a year? And above all, what the fuck were they eating for months in that place? Did they ever have a bath? It didnU+2019t even have a toilet for crying out loud.<br /><br />9) I am not even done yet; it gets even more convoluted. Aside from trying to find the seven items that hold VoltemortU+2019s power, everybody was also looking for three artifacts, which are again replaced all the time so nobody is certain which are the real ones and who are the current owners. By the time they figured out what is going on, the artifacts didnU+2019t matter anymore, so they might as well never had existed. Not to mention how Rowling threw in an extra quest and a bunch of background stories at the last moment which was making everything needlessly complicated.<br /><br />Dark Lord Harry Potter<br />And amidst this bullshit is Harry freaking Potter, behaving equally as evil as Voltemort did. Just list the things he did in this book, and compare them to what the Lord of all Evil was doing all this time.<br />- uses his allies as human shields so he can escape<br />- cowardly knocks people unconscious by backstabbing them without any warning<br />- tricks innocents into doing his bidding by impersonating someone they know<br />- frees from prison everyone who is against the government<br />- constantly penetrates places he shouldnU+2019t be in and causes chaos<br />- enslaves those who resist him by using the mind control spell<br />- hides like a coward under the invisibility cloak when his bullshit gets exposed<br />- pretends to be dead so he can get away with it<br />- pretends he came back from the dead only when the entire school is watching him so he can show off<br />ItU+2019s the exact same thing. And yet Rowling presents all that as heroic and thinks nobody is going to notice that because Voltemort looks like a fucking zombie while Harry is a victimized orphan. Fucking bullshit.<br /><br />No security<br />And of course the reason all that were possible is because there is no defense against anything in this stupid setting.<br /><br />1) There is no defense against the mind control spell. You can control anyone to do anything you want, even if itU+2019s against his will.<br /><br />2) There is no defense against invisibility or transmutation. Anyone can impersonate anyone else he likes and nobody will suspect a thing. You can infiltrate the most secure places on Earth in minutes because nobody pays attention to the magic alarms or has invented an anti magic barrier.<br /><br />3) There is no defense against elf magic. Even when Harry is imprisoned in a room that blocks teleportation, a house elf appears and frees him just like that. Why are they slaves when house elf magic is far more powerful that wizard magic and can do any shit they like? They can take over the world easier than Voltemort did.<br /><br />4) There is no defense against rebellious teenagers. As always, kids at the magic school were not obeying the adults, the teachers had no way to control them, or find the radio station where they were using for mocking the authorities. Also, teenagers could easily fend off huge armies of monsters despite being rookies who didnU+2019t know of a single offensive spell up until two years ago.<br /><br />5) There is no defense against secret passages. Hogwarts is filled with secret rooms nobody could find for a thousand years, and when Harry finds them pretty easily, they are constantly used by the rebellious teenagers, and again nobody else could find them. The adults kept saying that they blocked every single secret exist in Hogwarts, and yet Harry and the teenagers kept using even more exits to easily go in and out any time they wanted. They even went as far as evacuating the whole school despite being under siege by a huge army of monsters.<br /><br />6) There is no defense against good. Did you notice that throughout the whole story there are a dozen ways to fend off evil but nothing to fend off goodness? The secret room the teenagers were hiding in was Voltemort protected; meaning nobody who was evil could get in. On the other hand, the chamber of secrets from the second book, created so it can be used only by the Slitherin, does not have protection against any other faction.<br /><br />7) The bad guys have defenses that work only against them. They use monsters like basilisks and dragons, and spells like fiendfyre that can destroy the items holding VoltemortU+2019s power. No beast on the side of the good guys ever used it power against them. Furthermore, even after the chamber of secrets is revealed and the basilisk is killed, nobody from VoltemortU+2019s side bothers to take away the corpse despite knowing very well of its power. Also, the special password one must use to get into the chamber is in snaketongue, which despite being hyped up as something super special, anyone can get into the chamber by simply repeating the words without having to actually know the language. And of course itU+2019s so simple to remember something you heard once, 5 years ago, without feeling the need to memorize it. This plot armor is insane; the good guys can do anything, the bad guys can do shit.<br /><br />8) There is no defense against faking death. While Harry was faking his demise, nobody bothered to check his pulse and make sure he is really dead.<br /><br />9) And even in that single time when adults finally try to protect something, the booby trap they use is overkill and causes more damage than benefit.<br />- What kind of a madman would try to stop a thief by making the gold in a treasury to multiply and turn to lava? You are effectively destroying everything you are guarding this way.<br />- Also, what is the point of having a treasury when there is a spell that multiplies gold? Precious metals have no value when you can do that.<br />- And as if that wasnU+2019t enough, they even had a dragon guarding the gold. How does having a huge monster stepping on the precious artifacts and breathing fire on what you are supposed to guard, counts as protecting them?<br />- Also, how do you expect the dragon to fight the thieves when you turn the gold he is sitting on to lava?<br />- Also, what is the point of having a dragon as a guard when a few tiny goblins can scare it and a little boy can tame it in a few seconds?<br />- Also, did anyone notice that Harry essentially enslaved Goblins, used them as robots, and then abandoned them to be burned alive by the gold, while he shows off by riding the dragon.<br />- The idea to make the room immune to magic is a good defense but if no magic works in there, how does the gold magically multiplies and turns to lava and how could Harry cast a spell on the wall so he could escape?<br />- Also, how can you cast an enlargement spell on a hole, so you can make it bigger? A hole is empty space; there is nothing to enlarge. You are essentially shrinking the wall around it.<br />- Also, why is there a hole on the wall of a treasury? How are you guarding a place when you make it so easy for someone to sneak in?<br /><br />Awful romance<br />Now letU+2019s talk a bit about how good Rowling is at writing romance. Hermione falls in love with Ron in this book, because he abandoned her. Next thing you know, she French kisses him while they ripping off the teeth from a 5 year old rotting corpse of a Basilisk. ThatU+2019s so romantic Rowling, having them kiss for no reason while everything around them stinks like shit.<br /><br />Awful exposition<br />LetU+2019s also talk a bit about her wonderful exposition. Remember Snape who betrayed them in the previous book? Turns out he was faking it (thatU+2019s right, another fake) and that he is actually a good guy. Something that we the audience find out when he is already dead. He didnU+2019t even do something with his double crossing because Voltemort killed him before he had the chance to move against him. And Voltemort didnU+2019t even kill him because he found out he was a traitor. He just did it for fun, effectively making SnapeU+2019s side story completely pointless.<br /><br />Bullshit action<br />After that, the final battle takes place and you are left wondering when did these rookie teenagers learn all these powerful spells when two years ago they couldnU+2019t even wave a wand properly? Most of them were not even mentioned or explained before. And why donU+2019t they simply spam the enslavement spell? ItU+2019s easy to cast and can turn the enemy against himself. Or better yet, why donU+2019t they all drink the luck potion and sit back as the monsters get killed by their own attacks? See what happens when you abuse magic?<br /><br />Anticlimactic ending<br />And then we finally get to Harry fighting Voltemort. This has to be epic, right? ItU+2019s the final battle, it just has to be. And it isnU+2019t! Harry wins by doing fucking nothing. VoltemortU+2019s spell bounces back and kills him in the exact same way as before. Fucking horseshit. Harry did zero things in the whole story and the villain defeated himself three times in a row. These books are garbage and anyone who still defends them is a filthy casual who doesnU+2019t like good storytelling, logical plot, proper foreshadowing, proper action scenes, or anything related to good writing. The end.</span>  <a data-text-id="15527524303689071825" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext none;'></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1356532054' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 1356532054, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_14715097" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/14715097" />    <a title="Marty" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/848564-marty"><img alt="Marty" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1202315158p2/848564.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/14715097?book_show_action=false">Feb 06, 2008</a>      <a title="Marty" class="user" name="Marty" href="/user/show/848564-marty">Marty</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/848564-marty?shelf=front-room-bookshelf">front-room-bookshelf</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer14715097" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4839229500001394516">Phew. I just felt as if I finally got the vaccine for a deadly epidemic going around. The epidemic, of course, would be all those people who want to talk about Harry Potter without me having read the last book. The vaccine, then, would be finally reading the book. I suppose that last comparison isn't exactly flattering, but don't let my poor comparison interfere in any way with the greatness of this book/series. <br /><br />In my last review of Harry Potter and the Half Blood Prince, I complained about havi</span>  <span id="freeText4839229500001394516" style="display:none">Phew. I just felt as if I finally got the vaccine for a deadly epidemic going around. The epidemic, of course, would be all those people who want to talk about Harry Potter without me having read the last book. The vaccine, then, would be finally reading the book. I suppose that last comparison isn't exactly flattering, but don't let my poor comparison interfere in any way with the greatness of this book/series. <br /><br />In my last review of Harry Potter and the Half Blood Prince, I complained about having to set apart time for reading Potter books since my life grinds to a halt until I finish. Last time it was a week of scout camp that came to my rescue. This time, however, I knew there was no way I would last until summer without a major plot point being revealed, but I was so dreadfully busy I could not fathom how I could find any time to squeeze the Deathly Hallows in. Cue an ugly stomach sickness. I never thought I would be so glad to be sick in all my life. My churning, volcanic stomach was the perfect excuse to pick up Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows. And this time I didn't need a week; I only needed two days (which for me, usually a deliberate reader, was quite an accomplishment). <br /><br />Ever since the Prisoner of Azkaban, I've always known that the Harry Potter books were a unique endeavor and a noted achievement. But it wasn't until Deathly Hallows, after being zipped around, yanked from one place to another, rocketed towards the finale, and then masterfully escorted through a complicated, yet brilliant and succinct climax, that I realized that I was reading one of the finest pieces of literature that I've ever set my hands on--not a conlcusion that I came to lightly. It wasn't until the conclusion that I realized that the Harry Potter series is more than just a really great story with an extremely clever plot--Harry Potter is a written work that exposes truths of human nature and experience in a way that few other authors, contemporary or "classic," are able to achieve. As I read through the final chapters, I realized that I was reading something that would be attached to my inner core for the rest of my life, and while I might forget details, I would never forget that Rowling really struck the right note, really revealed truths ... and who would have thought she would have done it with a seventeen year old wizard and his friends? <br /><br />As for the book itself, it starts out quickly and already, even with the Dursleys, hints towards the reconciliation that you find throughout the book. The middle part of the book plods, but even as I read and recognized this, I knew it was on purpose. The slowing of the plot reflected the experience of Harry, Hermione, and Ron and sets the reader in the mood for what the characters are going through. And just when you are about to say that you've had enough, Rowling starts the quick unraveling until the very end. Momentum picks up, problems are solved, but even more remain unresolved, the escapes and close calls mount until you feel as if you're reading one per page. Everything is set up for an impressive, epic, and final showdown, and this is where Rowling takes her masterful stroke. She stops everything. In the thick of the action, she stops it all and has some time for reflection. Certainly daring, but such a move in any other circumstance might be considered unwise at the least and extreme folly at the most (I believe Ron would call it "mental"). In this case, it's brilliant. It refocuses the story on what really matters, why it matters to us as readers, and makes all of the epic preparations seem paltry compared to the thoughts and reflections of the protagonist that we feast on at the end. When the climax comes, you're already satisfied--you don't even care how it turns out because Rowling has taught you something true that will ring true no matter what else happens. And, while she did skim over some of the loose ends in the plot extremely quickly after that point, I think I prefer that to a long, drawn out explanation at the end. She made her point, and I didn't need to see anything else. For that matter, neither do you. If you haven't had the vaccine yet, get it.<br /><br />Thank you, J.K. Rowling. <br /></span>  <a data-text-id="4839229500001394516" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review14715097">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id='like_container_review_14715097'><a id="like_count_review_14715097" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/14715097?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">7 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_14715097" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_14715097" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=7&rating[page]=10&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=14715097&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_14715097" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 14715097, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">3 comments</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/14715097?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=10">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_14715097' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/14715097/comments?reverse=true">View all 3 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_14715097' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 14715097, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_29339744" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/29339744" />    <a title="Jamie" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1385106-jamie"><img alt="Jamie" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1217535570p2/1385106.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/29339744?book_show_action=false">Aug 05, 2008</a>      <a title="Jamie" class="user" name="Jamie" href="/user/show/1385106-jamie">Jamie</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">                  <em>                    This review has been hidden because it contains spoilers. To view it,                    <a href="#" onclick="Effect.toggle(&#39;reviewTextContainer29339744&#39;); return false;">click here.</a>                  </em>              <span id="reviewTextContainer29339744" class="readable"                    style="display:none"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer7260801654086650773">Like every other being on the English-speaking parts of the planet, I picked up J.K. Rowling's new Harry Potter book on the day it came out. This is the final Potter, and after 10 years of following the series I was pretty interested to see how it would all turn out with Harry and his coterie are on the lamb and everything is going to hell now that the chief bad guy is seizing control of the wizarding world.<br /><br />One of the things that I've always admired about this series is how they started off bein</span>  <span id="freeText7260801654086650773" style="display:none">Like every other being on the English-speaking parts of the planet, I picked up J.K. Rowling's new Harry Potter book on the day it came out. This is the final Potter, and after 10 years of following the series I was pretty interested to see how it would all turn out with Harry and his coterie are on the lamb and everything is going to hell now that the chief bad guy is seizing control of the wizarding world.<br /><br />One of the things that I've always admired about this series is how they started off being childish and fanciful, then matured into more and more sophisticated, dark, and --oddly enough-- realistic books. The Deathly Hallows takes this trend to its conclusion, and not just because the body count is so alarmingly high by the end. I loved how this book looks full into the face of an issue that every one of us has had to deal with on our road towards adulthood: adults are flawed and fallible. And I'm not just talking about the bad guys here. I mean our friends fail us. Our authority figures fail us. Our parents fail us. But it's only because they're real, complex people and we can't see that until we've done some aging ourselves. I loved how Hallows expands on this theme by showing us how people like Dumbledore and even Harry's dad were, at least once, worse people than we thought they were, and how others like Snape and even the Malfoys are better than we thought they were. Rowling teases apart the simple, bold lines she used to draw her characters in the beginning of the series so that they are now possessed of shades and nuances that weren't there before. And yet it flows naturally and you can see that the groundwork was often laid thousands of pages ago.<br /><br />The other thing to love about Hallows is, of course, that it's a rip-roaring good adventure. Despite the disappointing fact that it falls back on the tired old cliche of the quest to collect all the magicle foozles (actually, there are two sets of foozles in play here) so they can be combined/destroyed lest they save/explode the world, our favorite wizardly teens go from one exciting scene to the next. Well, mostly. I could have done with a lot less of the clomping around in the woods that goes on in the middle of the book, but otherwise it's just good entertainment. And things culminate in (MINOR SPOILER!!) a battle royale at Hogwarts towards the end of the book in which just about every major and minor character from the series gets called in to take the safeties off their wands and totally cut loose. That was just plain fun.<br /><br />I did have a few problems with the book, but they were mostly minor. It dragged in the middle, as I said, to the point where it seemed like Rowling was just padding it out. I had also have had QUITE enough of Emo Potter and his hissy fit ways in the previous couple of installments, so that I was banging the book against my head when Harry started to get all pissy and emotional to the point of sundering his friendships. Thankfully Rowling moved on, in the name of character development if nothing else.<br /><br />My only substantial disappointment with Gallows was how it lacked the sense of discovery and world building that earlier books had. What I loved about the early parts of the series was that Rowling's impressive imagination was on full display, meted out in revelations about the wizarding world, its mechanics, its societies, its places, its people, and its, well, magic. I loved finding out what she was going to think of next because it was entertaining and delightful. Hallows, on the other hand, is in full wrap-up mode. We get very little new except the chaos and loss that came out of breaking down everything we had come to know at that point. Still, I guess Rowling had to stop introducing new stuff at some point so that she could wrap it up even if the sense of wonder and discovery is greatly reduced.<br /><br />So, thumbs up from me. The last 100 pages of the book create what is one of the most satisfying endings to an epic series that I can remember, and I'm really glad I've read the books. I hope that my kids read and enjoy them some day. It'll be fun to talk about them.</span>  <a data-text-id="7260801654086650773" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div U+0647 U+202B U+2026.U+202C<br>U+200E U+0645 U+0648 U+062A U+062F U+0648 U+0628 U+064A U+0627 U+062B U+0631 U+0641 U+064A U+0627 U+062C U+062F U+0627 U+202B U+2026 U+202C U+062D U+0642 U+064A U+0642 U+062D U+0628 U+0643 U+0644 U+062F U+0645 U+0628 U+0644 U+062F U+0648 U+0631 U+0648 U+0643 U+0631 U+0647 U+0643 U+0644 U+062A U+0648 U+0645 U+0631 U+064A U+062F U+0644 U+0634 U+0626 U+0645 U+062A U+0646 U+0627 U+0642 U+0636 U+202B..U+202C U+0644 U+0627 U+0646 U+0647 U+062A U+0634 U+0627 U+0628 U+0647 U+0627 U+0644 U+0643 U+0628 U+064A U+0631 U+0641 U+064A U+062D U+064A U+0627 U+0629 U+0643 U+0644 U+0645 U+0646 U+0647 U+0645 U+0648 U+0627 U+0636 U+062D U+0648 U+0628 U+062D U+062B U+0647 U+0645 U+0639 U+0646 U+062E U+0644 U+0648 U+062F U+0648 U+0627 U+0636 U+062D U+202B..U+202C U+0648 U+0637 U+0628 U+0639 U+0627 U+0627 U+0648 U+0636 U+062D U+0627 U+0646 U+0644 U+064A U+0633 U+0647 U+0646 U+0627 U+0643 U+0634 U+062E U+0635 U+0643 U+0627 U+0645 U+0644 U+0641 U+064A U+0633 U+0631 U+062F U+062D U+064A U+0627 U+0629 U+0627 U+0644 U+0633 U+0631 U+064A U+0629 U+0644 U+062F U+0645 U+0628 U+0644 U+062F U+0648 U+0631 U+202B..U+202C U+0644 U+0647 U+0630 U+0627 U+062D U+0628 U+0643 U+0644 U+0634 U+062E U+0635 U+0648 U+0643 U+0631 U+0647 U+0645 U+0644 U+064A U+0627 U+062E U+0631 U+0645 U+0634 U+0627 U+0628 U+0647 U+062A U+0646 U+0627 U+0642 U+0636 U+0641 U+0627 U+0636 U+062D U+202B..!U+202C<br><br>U+200E U+0644 U+062F U+064A U+0627 U+0644 U+0643 U+062B U+064A U+0631 U+0645 U+0646 U+0643 U+0644 U+0627 U+0645 U+0644 U+0643 U+0644 U+0634 U+062E U+0635 U+064A U+0629 U+0645 U+0646 U+0647 U+0627 U+062F U+0644 U+0644 U+064A U+0648 U+0639 U+0627 U+0626 U+0644 U+0629 U+0645 U+0627 U+0644 U+0641 U+0648 U+064A U+0648 U+0646 U+064A U+0644 U+0644 U+0643 U+0646 U+0627 U+0644 U+0645 U+0633 U+0627 U+062D U+0629 U+0644 U+0627 U+062A U+0633 U+0645 U+062D U+0644 U+0627 U+0646 U+0647 U+0645 U+0643 U+0627 U+0646 U+0644 U+062A U+0639 U+0642 U+064A U+0628 U+0628 U+0633 U+064A U+0637 U+062C U+062F U+0627 U+202B..!U+202C<br><br>U+200E U+0628 U+0639 U+062F U+0646 U+0647 U+0627 U+064A U+0629 U+0627 U+0644 U+0645 U+0644 U+062D U+0645 U+0629 U+064A U+062C U+0628 U+0627 U+0646 U+0646 U+0639 U+062A U+0631 U+0641 U+0627 U+0646 U+0628 U+0637 U+0644 U+0631 U+0648 U+0627 U+064A U+0629 U+0644 U+0645 U+064A U+0643 U+0646 U+0647 U+0627 U+0631 U+064A U+0628 U+0648 U+062A U+0631 U+202B U+2026 U+202C U+0628 U+0644 U+0643 U+0627 U+0646 U+062C U+0648 U+0627 U+0646 U+0643 U+0627 U+062B U+0644 U+064A U+0646 U+0631 U+0648 U+0644 U+064A U+0646 U+062C <br><br>U+200E U+0645 U+0646  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1354572748" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1354572748" />    <a title="Rebecca (whymermaids)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4713345-rebecca-whymermaids"><img alt="Rebecca (whymermaids)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1347213351p2/4713345.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1354572748?book_show_action=false">Aug 04, 2015</a>      <a title="Rebecca (whymermaids)" class="user" name="Rebecca (whymermaids)" href="/user/show/4713345-rebecca-whymermaids">Rebecca (whymermaids)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9780545583008" href="/book/show/17347379-harry-potter-and-the-deathly-hallows">review of another edition</a>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1354572748" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer11505430962879382244">The Deathly Hallows rips me apart in so many ways, and still leaves me with a feeling of hope and happiness. There's so much death and a loss of innocence, and some of these deaths STILL have me upset, and I read this book for the first time eight years ago. At the same time, however, it's a fantastic book, with great themes of acceptance, death, love, and good triumphing over evil, and it's a wonderful conclusion.<br /><br />Deathly Hallows takes chances, and that's something I appreciate about it. A lot o</span>  <span id="freeText11505430962879382244" style="display:none">The Deathly Hallows rips me apart in so many ways, and still leaves me with a feeling of hope and happiness. There's so much death and a loss of innocence, and some of these deaths STILL have me upset, and I read this book for the first time eight years ago. At the same time, however, it's a fantastic book, with great themes of acceptance, death, love, and good triumphing over evil, and it's a wonderful conclusion.<br /><br />Deathly Hallows takes chances, and that's something I appreciate about it. A lot of people have problems with the wandering around in forests stage of the book, but I think it's incredibly brave of Rowling to do, BECAUSE it is so anti-climatic. But that's REALISTIC. Harry, Ron, and Hermione are teenagers thrown into a world of death and destruction; all three are wanted by the Death Eaters for either being friends with muggle-borns or being one themselves. The world is in turmoil, and it's very much like World War II, with muggle-borns being persecuted and killed simply because of their birth status. There's a heavy prejudice in the wizarding world, and Harry and his friends are the only ones who can fix it. That's a lot of pressure for three 17-year-olds, especially as Dumbledore left them very little to go on. So OF COURSE they're going to spend a long time meandering about, trying to figure out what to do. <br /><br />That being said, once things get going, they go. There are some really great action sequences, and the Battle of Hogwarts is one of my favorites in all the books; it's rich, it's complex, it's sad, and it shows how much the characters have all grown. I also love the scene at Malfoy Manor and Gringotts, and the scene at Godric's Hollow still creeps me out.<br /><br />Deathly Hallows answers all the questions that have been brewing since Sorcerer's Stone, and does so in such an interesting, satisfying way. I love all the explanations of how and why things are, and Dumbledore's backstory is heartbreaking and wonderful to read.<br /><br />And oh, the tears. So many tears. Deathly Hallows is one of the few books I don't like to read in front of others; I need to be alone, so I can be with the characters and my grief of losing them, and coming to terms with the end of the series.<br /><br />THE ONE THING I WOULD CHANGE:<br /><br />There's a theory that says the prophecy, which states "Neither can live while the other survives" could mean that neither can die EXCEPT by the hand of the other, therefore making Harry immortal. I think this ending would have been a more powerful one, simply because at this point, Harry is not afraid of death. We know that. He's proven that to us. Death is the only way he can be with those he loves: his parents, Sirius, Lupin, etc; so isn't it MORE of a sacrifice for him to never die and join them? I think so. That's my only change I'd make. That, and the epilogue, simply because we didn't need it, and it was just too cheesy. I would've preferred to end with the trio, or with Harry alone. <br /><br />--<br /><br />I love Harry Potter. This reread has proven that the love is still there, still strong, and still a huge part of my life. When I got my Deathly Hallows/scar tattoo, my mom believed I'd regret it, that I'd "grow out" of Harry Potter. At this point, it's been 20 years since the first book came out, and I'm still in love with it as ever.</span>  <a data-text-id="11505430962879382244" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1354572748">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1354572748" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=7&rating[page]=10&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=1354572748&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_1354572748" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 1354572748, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">comment</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/1354572748?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=10">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1354572748' style='display: '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_473550287" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/473550287" />    <a title="Lucinda" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/6463881-lucinda"><img alt="Lucinda" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1437664381p2/6463881.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/473550287?book_show_action=false">Dec 09, 2012</a>      <a title="Lucinda" class="user" name="Lucinda" href="/user/show/6463881-lucinda">Lucinda</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780747591054" href="/book/show/820343.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6463881-lucinda?shelf=harry-potter">harry-potter</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer473550287" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer18287123732891775456">*Note, Spoilers*<br /><br />The final installment within the most outstanding and truly amazing series ever that has entrenched itself within our lives eternally!!! <br /><br /><br />It all endsU+2026NO! As I picked up the last book in the highly acclaimed and spectacular Harry Potter series, I could not comprehend the fact that it was coming to an end. <br /><br />I began reading JK RowlingU+2019s incredible fantasy series when I was HarryU+2019s age at eleven and was thrust into the most remarkable world, where my dreams were brought vividly to life</span>  <span id="freeText18287123732891775456" style="display:none">*Note, Spoilers*<br /><br />The final installment within the most outstanding and truly amazing series ever that has entrenched itself within our lives eternally!!! <br /><br /><br />It all endsU+2026NO! As I picked up the last book in the highly acclaimed and spectacular Harry Potter series, I could not comprehend the fact that it was coming to an end. <br /><br />I began reading JK RowlingU+2019s incredible fantasy series when I was HarryU+2019s age at eleven and was thrust into the most remarkable world, where my dreams were brought vividly to life and which sparked my imagination so that it could soar cloud high. Her books have not only touched many childrenU+2019s lives but also teenagers who can relate to the three main characters of Harry, Ron and Hermione as they grow-up but also adults too because of the strong themes of love and death within. This series although fantasy and un-real (which I did believe to be real for many years!), is based on our own real world and lives as we explore life and death, human emotion and that most powerful of emotions; love. Harry is a significant part of my life for I have grown up with him and have experienced similar occurrences and happenings, as him and his other Hogwarts friends have for the writing epitomized a childU+2019s life and through teenage years; that were tough. HarryU+2019s story is one that touched my heart and soul and which is now buried deep within, as although it has ended it shall certainly live on forever in all of our lives as JK Rowling gave her gift to the world. <br /><br />In this spectacular, intensely gripping conclusion we follow Harry, Ron and Hermione as they leave the walls of Hogwarts School to embark on a journey into the unknown in search of the hidden Horcruxes, with the aim of defeating the darkness and killing Voldemort. The magical world has changed since the Death eaters took control of the Ministry of Magic (with the horrid Delores Umbridge at its centre), and even within the school walls where no one is longer safe. As the number of killings per day rise the time is very much remicent of all those years ago when Voldemort rose to power last time, and so Harry and his friends must uncover the secrets before it is too late and before anyone else dear to him gets hurt. No one can be trusted as Nagini lies in wait for Harry when he takes a trip to see Godrics Hollow and the home of his parents, which is a real U+2018stingU+2019 and which is a stark reminder of what Harry is fighting for. As the great battle draws near and one by one members of the Order of the Phoenix succumb to the terrors of the dark mark, Hogwarts prepares to fight as too does everyone who holds love in their heartsU+2026full of epic battle scenes, heartache and the most cutting act of all when Belatrix Lestrange kills Dobby this is a book that really does tug at the heartstrings of human emotion and which pierced a hole in my heart so that I bled inwardly. <br /><br />The Harry Potter series is truly an astonishing piece of fiction and which has not only impacted upon our imaginations but upon life itself, hence what JK Rowling has achieved can only be described as something so great that not even a genius of their craft could compare. I cannot praise this fantastic, outstanding conclusion and the most thrilling, nail-biting, powerful ending to one of the greatest fictional series EVER therefore if I was able to give it a hundred stars I would (rather than 5)U+2026. <br /></span>  <a data-text-id="18287123732891775456" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div id='like_container_review_473550287'><a id="like_count_review_473550287" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/473550287?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">7 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_473550287" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_473550287" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_362649849" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/362649849" />    <a title="Rob" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/10743961-rob"><img alt="Rob" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1422270416p2/10743961.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/362649849?book_show_action=false">Aug 01, 2016</a>      <a title="Rob" class="user" name="Rob" href="/user/show/10743961-rob">Rob</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10743961-rob?shelf=harry-potter">harry-potter</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10743961-rob?shelf=audio-book">audio-book</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10743961-rob?shelf=read-before-goodreads">read-before-goodreads</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10743961-rob?shelf=read-2012">read-2012</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10743961-rob?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10743961-rob?shelf=not-a-bookclub-club">not-a-bookclub-club</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10743961-rob?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10743961-rob?shelf=read-2014">read-2014</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10743961-rob?shelf=own">own</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10743961-rob?shelf=author-female">author-female</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer362649849" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9112067254085883796"><b>Executive Summary:</b> This is a really great end to what has truly become and instant classic series. I'm a bit sad my re-visit is over, but I'm sure this won't be the last time I revisit this series.<br /><br /><b>Jim Audio Book:</b> I really enjoy Jim Dale. I imagine whatever I listen to in the near future will have an incredibly tough time measuring up.<br /><br /><b>Stephen Fry Audio Book:</b> I really enjoy Stephen Fry as well. Now that I've done the series with both, I still can't decide. If I had to pick, I think Dale is better</span>  <span id="freeText9112067254085883796" style="display:none"><b>Executive Summary:</b> This is a really great end to what has truly become and instant classic series. I'm a bit sad my re-visit is over, but I'm sure this won't be the last time I revisit this series.<br /><br /><b>Jim Audio Book:</b> I really enjoy Jim Dale. I imagine whatever I listen to in the near future will have an incredibly tough time measuring up.<br /><br /><b>Stephen Fry Audio Book:</b> I really enjoy Stephen Fry as well. Now that I've done the series with both, I still can't decide. If I had to pick, I think Dale is better for the earlier lighter books and Fry is better for the later darker ones, but you really can't go wrong either way.<br /><br /><b>  <u>Full Review </u></b><br />I originally gave this book a 5, but dropped it to a 4. On this re-read I up-rated <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/5.Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban__Harry_Potter___3_" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (Harry Potter, #3) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</a> because it was better than I remember. This book didn't quite hold up. It's a high 4 though.<br /><br />Early on I was definite I wanted to drop it 4, but as I got closer to the end I was less sure. I'm still a little iffy on it. This is really a story of two halves. The first half is slow sometimes to the point of being tedious.<br /><br />I'm not sure if it was intentional or not. I certainly felt as frustrated as the characters at their lack of progress.<br /><br />The second half of the book is truly excellent. The first part is what spoils a 5 star for me though. I'm trying to be a bit more frugal with what I give 5 stars to, to give that rating a bit more meaning. Cover to Cover this book just wasn't as enjoyable to me as <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/5.Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban__Harry_Potter___3_" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (Harry Potter, #3) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</a> or <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/6.Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire__Harry_Potter___4_" title="Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (Harry Potter, #4) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire</a>.<br /><br />That said, I love this book and I for one am happy with the ending. I have this perception that many(some?) people were upset at the epilogue. I've heard complaints that Ms. Rowling left nothing to the imagination.<br /><br />In some books that would bother me. For Harry Potter, it does not. I think if I had to imagine what would happen next, the Epilogue is exactly what I'd have wanted.</span>  <a data-text-id="9112067254085883796" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review362649849">  <td  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_5512387" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/5512387" />    <a title="Leanna" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/335117-leanna"><img alt="Leanna" src="https://s.gr-assets.com/assets/nophoto/user/f_5f-6a03a5c12233c941481992b82eea8d23.png" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/5512387?book_show_action=false">Sep 04, 2007</a>      <a title="Leanna" class="user" name="Leanna" href="/user/show/335117-leanna">Leanna</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer5512387" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer6925845959773999789"><br />My eyes are bleary, my head aches, and IU+2019m a bit of a grump. The culprit? Harry Potter. I stayed up until the wee hours of the morning finishing Harry Potter and the Deathly Hollows. My drive to finish the book wasnU+2019t fanaticismU+2014it was spoilers. I work in a library, and libraries are full of the kind of nerds who read Harry Potter and canU+2019t wait to talk about it. I knew if I didnU+2019t finish the book before work, it would be ruined for me.<br /><br />Keeping this in mind, I will not ruin the book for anyone el</span>  <span id="freeText6925845959773999789" style="display:none"><br />My eyes are bleary, my head aches, and IU+2019m a bit of a grump. The culprit? Harry Potter. I stayed up until the wee hours of the morning finishing Harry Potter and the Deathly Hollows. My drive to finish the book wasnU+2019t fanaticismU+2014it was spoilers. I work in a library, and libraries are full of the kind of nerds who read Harry Potter and canU+2019t wait to talk about it. I knew if I didnU+2019t finish the book before work, it would be ruined for me.<br /><br />Keeping this in mind, I will not ruin the book for anyone else. Instead, IU+2019ll just make some general observations:<br /><br />Library employees have been speculating for days (actually years) about what would happen in the book. They have reread the previous six books for clues. I did not participate in this speculation because I am lucky if I can even remember what I wore last weekU+2014let alone the intricate details of books I read years ago. However, many of their speculations were correct, so kudos to them. <br />Like I mentioned before, I have little interest in moody teenagers, and this book abounds in them. There were several moments when I wanted to give both Harry and Ron a slap. They are on the most important journey of their lives and they act like petulant two year olds? Give me a break. <br />I hate unnecessary epilogues. They detract from the integrity of a book. That is all I shall say. <br />Just because she is a billionaire does not mean that J.K. Rowling does not need an editor. I may be drawn-and-quartered for saying so, but The Deathly Hollows was way too long. The book could have easily been half the length without sacrificing anything. In fact, chopping out all the unnecessary drivel would have made the book stronger. Do I have to know every single person who attends a wedding and what they are wearing? No. Another problem with making the book so long is that readers are rushed to get to the meat of the story and may lose out on important details in their hurry. <br />Of course, none of my criticisms will stop anyone from reading the book. After all, if you are reading the seventh book, in all likelihood, you have also read the six books before it. Having made such a huge commitment, The Deathly Hollows could be the worst book ever, and everyone would still read it just to know what happens. It isnU+2019t the worst book ever, and nothing could have stopped me from reading it either.</span>  <a data-text-id="6925845959773999789" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review5512387">  <td elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_174590225" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/174590225" />    <a title="Kiri" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1243457-kiri"><img alt="Kiri" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1213637278p2/1243457.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/174590225?book_show_action=false">Jun 07, 2011</a>      <a title="Kiri" class="user" name="Kiri" href="/user/show/1243457-kiri">Kiri</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1243457-kiri?shelf=fiction">fiction</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1243457-kiri?shelf=children-young-adult">children-young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1243457-kiri?shelf=scifi-fant">scifi-fant</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1243457-kiri?shelf=reviewed">reviewed</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer174590225" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3586081610954646191">A quick last waltz through the Harry Potter novels before I send the set off to school children (somewhere) where they will hopefully be read to pieces and loved for at least a few years. <br><br>This last novel has many plotlines to wrap-up and covers the disillusionment that happens as we come of age and into the adult world. Admittedly Harry is coming to it at a very dark time in this fictional universe but Rowling does show the tears that happen and the depth of questioning that is left behind when</span>  <span id="freeText3586081610954646191" style="display:none">A quick last waltz through the Harry Potter novels before I send the set off to school children (somewhere) where they will hopefully be read to pieces and loved for at least a few years. <br><br>This last novel has many plotlines to wrap-up and covers the disillusionment that happens as we come of age and into the adult world. Admittedly Harry is coming to it at a very dark time in this fictional universe but Rowling does show the tears that happen and the depth of questioning that is left behind when we lose someone. <br><br>There is a great deal of wandering about aimlessly. It might have been illustrated with less prosaic filler unless of course there was a need to depict every ... last.. campsite .. they ... stopped .. at.. While worthy of a travelogue it drags on -- making the novel drag, not to mention the loss of time perspective by the core characters is a bit silly (they were getting papers) and at the very least I don't think Hermione is that un-organized. <br><br>I feel there were a few odd things about this novel. For one it isn't ever quite explained why Ron must be the one to destroy the locket horcrux - unless it is as a method to illustrate what the reader should have found obvious about his feelings regarding his two best friends. It might have been better addressed in another manner, however it does bring him back into the main plotline and gives him something to do. For another how did Neville get the sword after the goblin took it? <i>(Possibly I might have missed that bit but I don't think so)</i><br><br>But despite all of that we find out quite a bit as the novel goes on its way. There are highs and lows emotionally, as well as challenges. The end is of course quite exciting and while fans are left with the taste for more I felt it wrapped up quite well all things considered. <br><br>I'd like to also take a moment and make note of the lovely illustrations throughout the novels of this series done by Mary GrandPrU+00E9. They are delightful. <br><br>I will leave you with an amusing image that has little to do with my reading of this last novel in the series.. just my amusement. <br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1380351129i/704834.png" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></span>  <a data-text-id="3586081610954646191" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview"
