class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/42547066" />    <a title="Manny" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1713956-manny"><img alt="Manny" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1442491692p2/1713956.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/42547066?book_show_action=false">Jan 10, 2009</a>      <a title="Manny" class="user" name="Manny" href="/user/show/1713956-manny">Manny</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1713956-manny?shelf=trash">trash</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1713956-manny?shelf=children">children</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer42547066" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17489859557993937389">A few minutes after midnight on the release day for The Most Overhyped Book Of All Time, I logged in to Wikipedia and skimmed the plot to see which characters did in fact get killed at the end. Evidently some contributor had had it all wrapped up, and was just waiting for the starting pistol. The next day, I told several Potter fans what I'd done, and quite enjoyed the moment of dead silence that typically greeted my announcement.<br /><br />I'm sorry if this was disrespectful towards the author, but I wasn</span>  <span id="freeText17489859557993937389" style="display:none">A few minutes after midnight on the release day for The Most Overhyped Book Of All Time, I logged in to Wikipedia and skimmed the plot to see which characters did in fact get killed at the end. Evidently some contributor had had it all wrapped up, and was just waiting for the starting pistol. The next day, I told several Potter fans what I'd done, and quite enjoyed the moment of dead silence that typically greeted my announcement.<br /><br />I'm sorry if this was disrespectful towards the author, but I wasn't burning books, or publicly releasing spoilers, or anything like that. I later borrowed my son's copy and actually read it. With competent editing, I think Potter 7 could perhaps have been quite reasonable. I wonder if J.K. Rowling was genuinely pleased with her work, or just with the enormous amount of money it made for her? My impression was that she wasn't really having fun after the third or fourth volume, but I could be wrong.<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="17489859557993937389" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review42547066">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link42547066" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=42547066&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/136251.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_42547066'><a id="like_count_review_42547066" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/42547066?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">29 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_42547066" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_42547066" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=29&rating[page]=3&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=42547066&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_42547066" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 42547066, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">51 comments</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/42547066?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=3">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_42547066' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/42547066/comments?reverse=true">View all 51 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div><div id="comment_147746484" class="brown_comment">  <div class="xhr_comment_photo">    t<a alt="Lynne" href="/user/show/6133005-lynne"><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1334267311p1/6133005.jpg" alt="6133005" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/6133005-lynne">Lynne</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer7007791583313809701">Manny, I was born before the moon landing, thus I believe I have some of that life experience to which you referred. I've read Madame Bovary thrice,</span>  <span id="freeText7007791583313809701" style="display:none">Manny, I was born before the moon landing, thus I believe I have some of that life experience to which you referred. I've read Madame Bovary thrice, in French, only because I have a Master's Degree in French Literature and was forced to read it. The only thing I took from that story is that Emma Bovary was an insufferable twit who didn't deserve her privileged life. As a woman who has been married to a man 10 years my senior for quite awhile now, I thoroughly understand Emma's predicament. I don't understand her reactions to her life, however, and I'm not sure there is much of a lesson there. I've found much more valuable life lessons in the Harry Potter series than I ever found in Flaubert. I've read the HP series several times through and always come away with a new epiphany.</span>  <a data-text-id="7007791583313809701" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1676423924" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1108867092" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1108867092" />    <a title="Edward Lorn" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/8850418-edward-lorn"><img alt="Edward Lorn" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1478625849p2/8850418.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1108867092?book_show_action=false">Jan 21, 2016</a>      <a title="Edward Lorn" class="user" name="Edward Lorn" href="/user/show/8850418-edward-lorn">Edward Lorn</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <div><span class="uitext greyText">Recommends it for: </span>           <span class="uitext reviewText">Molesters of unicorns and wand strokers.</span></div>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/8850418-edward-lorn?shelf=audio-books">audio-books</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1108867092" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer716806270619434785">3.5 Stars<br /><br />Generally, I'm not a big fan of continuous-storyline series, and the Harry Potter series is a good example of why. I'm too much of a completionist, too OCD for this shit. Even though I rated most of these books below three stars, I felt compelled to finish them because I started them. Even after it took me six months to read GOBLET OF FIRE, I pressed forward. Even though I one-starred ORDER OF THE PHOENIX, I continued on. I had to know why people love these books as much as they do. At</span>  <span id="freeText716806270619434785" style="display:none">3.5 Stars<br /><br />Generally, I'm not a big fan of continuous-storyline series, and the Harry Potter series is a good example of why. I'm too much of a completionist, too OCD for this shit. Even though I rated most of these books below three stars, I felt compelled to finish them because I started them. Even after it took me six months to read GOBLET OF FIRE, I pressed forward. Even though I one-starred ORDER OF THE PHOENIX, I continued on. I had to know why people love these books as much as they do. At least I got my answer.<br /><br />J.K. Rowling did one major thing right with this series. Her writing matured along with her readers. As Potter got older and wiser, so did Rowling's style. This helped her quite a bit because the first three novels are horribly formulaic. But how many middle-grade kids are going to dissect overused plot points and cliched story structure? Not many. And by the time her audience was old enough to start questioning the borrowed ideas and storylines, Rowling had already established her characters and readied her pawns for battle. Had the series maintained the goofy middle-grade tone throughout, it would have likely failed. Had the first three books been as dark as the final four, the series wouldn't have seen half the success it did. In the end, it became a phenomenon because it spoke to the proper age groups at the proper times.<br /><br />I give this series a lot of grief, but not even my cynical ass can ignore Rowling's accomplishments. After writing this series, she went from homeless mother to one of the richest people on the face of the planet. Good for her. But I think her greatest success was getting kids reading again. And while I do not fan flail over these books, I do understand the draw. I understand the nostalgia and fond memories they invoke in their readers. <br /><br />THE DEATHLY HALLOWS was a little heavy in the middle. Its belly meandered and dragged some, but I was never bored to the point I was with PHOENIX. Then again, I think a lot of what I enjoyed about this book stemmed from the knowledge that I was reading the last one in the series. That thought alone made me smile and was a big reason I didn't want to put the book down.<br /><br />I'm glad Neville got his time in the sun, but Snape's story arc was my favorite of the bunch. Luna was another one I liked. Harry didn't really shine for me until book six, and I fucking loathed everything about Ron. I wanted Hermione and Draco to end up together, as they seemed hellbent for each other, but maybe that was just me reading too much into their hatred of one another. I kept expecting Harry to catch them rage fucking in a closet between classes.<br /><br />Finally, I'm pretty sure Peeves and Trelawney were screwing each other every time they were able. Next time you reread this, see if you can catch why I say that. <br /><br />The scene I remember the best out of the entire series is the underwater stuff in GOBLET. <br /><br />In summation: Six easy reads and one big pile of shit equal a series that owes a lot to young readers and nostalgia. Books six and seven are clearly the best of the bunch. If I had to rate the series as a whole, I'd have to give it three stars. <br /><br /><b>Final Judgment: Done at last. Done at last. Thank Tom Cruise almighty I'm done at last!</b><br /><br /><i>A rundown of my ratings for each book:<br /><br />The Sorcerer's Stone ***<br />The Chamber of Secrets ***<br />The Prisoner of Azkaban **<br />The Goblet of Fire **** (Wow... I don't remember liking this one enough to give it 4 stars... Odd.)<br />The Order of the Phoenix * (I want to give this book zero stars, or, preferably, a minus 3)<br />The Half-Blood Prince ****<br />The Deathly Hallows ***1/2<br /><br /><br /></i></span>  <a data-text-id="716806270619434785" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1108867092" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1108867092" ref="like" class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_3232458" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/3232458" />    <a title="J.G. Keely" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/84023-j-g-keely"><img alt="J.G. Keely" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1274333636p2/84023.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/3232458?book_show_action=false">Jul 30, 2007</a>      <a title="J.G. Keely" class="user" name="J.G. Keely" href="/user/show/84023-j-g-keely">J.G. Keely</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/84023-j-g-keely?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/84023-j-g-keely?shelf=contemporary-fiction">contemporary-fiction</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/84023-j-g-keely?shelf=novel">novel</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/84023-j-g-keely?shelf=reviewed">reviewed</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/84023-j-g-keely?shelf=contemporary-fantasy">contemporary-fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/84023-j-g-keely?shelf=uk-and-ireland">uk-and-ireland</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer3232458" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer14635003514861086625">Too expository, same disjointed plotting as ever. Nothing particularly surprising or shocking. Gains more strength through familiar characters and nostalgia than from new developments or understandings. Smacks of the improbably untragic wars of any happy ending; though Rowling's wealth of secondary characters provides a little fodder.<br /><br />Character growth in the likes of Dumbledore, Neville, Kreacher, and the predictably D'arcy-like Snape provide the most interest in the book. Perhaps Rowling was mor</span>  <span id="freeText14635003514861086625" style="display:none">Too expository, same disjointed plotting as ever. Nothing particularly surprising or shocking. Gains more strength through familiar characters and nostalgia than from new developments or understandings. Smacks of the improbably untragic wars of any happy ending; though Rowling's wealth of secondary characters provides a little fodder.<br /><br />Character growth in the likes of Dumbledore, Neville, Kreacher, and the predictably D'arcy-like Snape provide the most interest in the book. Perhaps Rowling was more concerned with closure than constructing a more complex story. Then again, she may just be glad to be free of it after all these years. I do congratulate her on getting out while the getting was good.<br /><br />The epilogue particularly felt like an attempt to make an utter and unapologetic finish to the story. Unfortunately, it will likely not keep the questions at bay. I, myself, couldn't but wonder if the older Harry might have adopted a fatherly middle-class mustache. I'll have to pen a letter.<br /><br />Despite the claims that the books were plotted out and foreshadowed from the beginning, we get a lot of last-minute additions to the world to build toward a convenient <a href="http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlotCoupon" rel="nofollow">plot coupon</a> ending. Rowling was, more-or-less, beyond the power of editors, and I wish she had used that power to write an interesting, audacious book, but this ending was very safe, and free from the surprising plot twists Rowling sometimes managed.<br /><br />I guess she was trying to please her fans, but she had a lot of people to please. Hopefully she pleased some of them, but I was disappointed that as the series neared its end, it became less quirky and character-driven, and more predictable and cliche.<br /><br /><a href="http://starsbeetlesandfools.blogspot.com/2012/06/suggested-readings-in-fantasy.html" rel="nofollow">My Fantasy Book Suggestions</a></span>  <a data-text-id="14635003514861086625" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview"  </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer80616286" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10400876956860410463">I've just finished rereading this for the fourth or fifth time, eight years after its release. Still, I found myself an absolute teary mess during chapter 34 - 'The Forest Again'. Coincidentally, Rowling has stated this is her own favourite chapter. The Prince's Tale and the deaths of Fred and Lupin still make my eyes water, but nothing compares to those scenes in the forest. Rowling deserves every little bit of her success. This is a fantastic conclusion to an unbelievable story. She is a true</span>  <span id="freeText10400876956860410463" style="display:none">I've just finished rereading this for the fourth or fifth time, eight years after its release. Still, I found myself an absolute teary mess during chapter 34 - 'The Forest Again'. Coincidentally, Rowling has stated this is her own favourite chapter. The Prince's Tale and the deaths of Fred and Lupin still make my eyes water, but nothing compares to those scenes in the forest. Rowling deserves every little bit of her success. This is a fantastic conclusion to an unbelievable story. She is a true rarity; a fantastic author and an even better storyteller. <br /><br /><i>U+201CDo not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all, those who live without love.U+201D</i></span>  <a data-text-id="10400876956860410463" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a> </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1351084816" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1351084816" />    <a title="Nnenna" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/8256027-nnenna"><img alt="Nnenna" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1422412205p2/8256027.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1351084816?book_show_action=false">Aug 01, 2015</a>      <a title="Nnenna" class="user" name="Nnenna" href="/user/show/8256027-nnenna">Nnenna</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1351084816" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5008112265694772739">What an ending! I'm so happy that I've finally read the series from beginning to end. Now people can hit me with all their Harry Potter references! ;)</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1351084816">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1351084816" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1351084816&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/136251.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1351084816'><a id="like_count_review_1351084816" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1351084816?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">25 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1351084816" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1351084816" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=25&rating[page]=3&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=1351084816&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_1351084816" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 1351084816, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">comment</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/1351084816?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=3">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1351084816' style='display: elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_38710105" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/38710105" />    <a title="Mephistia" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1178739-mephistia"><img alt="Mephistia" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1409507082p2/1178739.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/38710105?book_show_action=false">Aug 05, 2015</a>      <a title="Mephistia" class="user" name="Mephistia" href="/user/show/1178739-mephistia">Mephistia</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">did not like it</span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1178739-mephistia?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer38710105" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer7680599343446643493">I was stunned and dismayed by the time I finished this book. I have been a fan of the HP series since about 2000, when a friend recommended Book 1 to me as a cute little book that she was tutoring 5th graders with. I read it, liked it, and figured I'd pick up the next book when it came out.<br /><br />As each book came out, many critics and fans commented that JK had a unique style of approaching her series; the way that her books grew with her targeted audience. The series became darker and more complex, t</span>  <span id="freeText7680599343446643493" style="display:none">I was stunned and dismayed by the time I finished this book. I have been a fan of the HP series since about 2000, when a friend recommended Book 1 to me as a cute little book that she was tutoring 5th graders with. I read it, liked it, and figured I'd pick up the next book when it came out.<br /><br />As each book came out, many critics and fans commented that JK had a unique style of approaching her series; the way that her books grew with her targeted audience. The series became darker and more complex, the writing more intense as the series continued.<br /><br />By the 5th book, I was well and truly hooked, and read each book voraciously when it came out. I re-read the entire available series just before the next book was released, and enjoyed them immensely.<br /><br />When Book 7 came out, I was disappointed, but only in the way that a fan is when what they have enjoyed so long is at an end. There would be no more HP books to look forward to. As I had not been part of HP online communities, nor did I enjoy the movies, this was the end of the series for me.<br /><br />Then I read the book, and I was furious. Six books she spent preaching about house unity, and how Hogwarts must unite or fall. Six books she spent warning of a terrible and devastating war that Harry would be in the thick of. Six books that were well enough written between plot and description that I could overlook her lack of characterization for antagonists or the fact that Ginny was essentially a flat character. <br /><br />And then book 7, where she completely ignores everything she spent 6 books setting up, skips around the reality of war by having Harry wander around lost on the moors for a bit, and then pulls a religious analogy out of her hat. <br /><br />Although the religious analogy did make me laugh -- I can't help but wonder if all those who said HP was the devil's work will be praising it like it's Narnia in 10 years.<br /><br />Still, I couldn't believe what she'd done to her work. I don't know if that honestly was her vision from the beginning, as she claims -- if it was, then the entire series suffers for it, and her vision is severely limited. The other alternative is that she sold out or simply didn't care because she's already richer than a queen. Whatever the reasoning, it was an awful, disappointing end to a beautifully textured series.<br /><br />---EDITED TO ADD---<br /><br />I still dislike book 7, although I love the rest of the series. I love how JK structured the books, right? I mean, she's a genius with the foreshadowing and with dropping in information about the characters backgrounds without being heavy handed. She's just a brilliant writer who structured these very rich, well-crafted worlds that hold up to multiple re-readings. <br /><br />I love how the books "grow" with the reader, with the first books being written for a younger reader and the later books being written for an older reader. Most of all, I love how she foreshadows across the books, so things that happen in, say, Book 5 are foreshadowed in Books 1 and 2. It's AMAZING. She's so incredibly talented, and it makes reading her books a real treat. Which was why I am still so incredibly upset at reading book 7. <br /><br />See, in Book 7, she brings up this whole notion of those three items (the Elder Wand, Invisibility Cloak, and Philosophers Stone) being tied together by the myth of the three brothers. That's the part that pissed me off. It felt ... cobbled in. Pulled out of a hat, last minute. Like, JK had told us about the numberless clock in the Weasley's house warning us about danger, about hunting for garden gnomes, about the time Ron's teddy bear got turned into a spider ... but she didn't mention this apparently incredibly common wizarding childrens story? <br /><br />She talks about all these daily aspects of wizarding life on a regular basis, introduced through Ron's family, but never once -- never once in 6 entire books does Ron or Ginny or anyone even let out a breath of a whisper about this apparently common wizarding fable? Think about how often you reference common fairy stories and fables in your life. Cinderella, Red Riding Hood, Big Bad Wold, etc. So if JK Rowling actually had this idea of a wizarding fable/myth as a major plot in her overarching series, I think she would have woven it in as foreshadowing much more effectively. What I think happened is this:<br /><br />Right around the time Book 7 was being written, all these internet/ social media/ fanboard sites were really taking off. They weren't huge before then, but they were really taking off as she'd released Books 5 & 6 and was writing book 7. I think that the fans had pretty much figured out what was happening, plot wise -- which is a mark of what a great writer JK Rowling is -- and JK felt bad about that -- which is a natural creative response.<br /><br />I think her publisher advised her to keep quiet about reading the fanboards for legal reasons, which she wisely did, but I fully believe she read them, and that she wasn't happy about two things:<br /><br />(1) The proliferation of fanfic and noncanon fanfic pairings<br />(2) How thoroughly the fans had guessed the key points of the plot (particularly what would be happening with Snape and Dumbledore and the Horcruxes).<br /><br />So I think that JK just sort of pulled that bit about the 3 Wizarding brothers and the ancient fairy tale and 3 legendary items out of her hat (with no foreshadowing regarding this plotline in the previous 6 books) because she wanted to surprise her fans with a sort of "gotcha"/ surprise moment. <br /><br />Furthermore, I suspect she wrote in the epilogue as a sort of middle finger to the proliferation of fanfic writers, as though to say, "And by the way, no. That is not how it happens. Harry and Hermoine do not end up together. Harry and Draco do not end up together. Ron and Pansy do not end up together. These people end up together, in these pairs. I do so decree it, and thus it shall be."<br /><br />So that's why I don't like Book: 7. I feel like it's less true to the ethos of the series than the rest of the books. I feel like JK Rowling kind of strayed from herself as a writer ... that she reacted (poorly) to her fans, and that it reflects badly on her work. I can't really enjoy reading the book even now. It feels out of step with the rest of the series.<br /><br />I've mostly moved on. I've forgiven her (even if the insult is imagined). She's a truly talented writer and generous and compassionate woman. She's an inspiration to me, as a writer. And it was a weird time in fandom and for the internet, when that book was being written. Everyone makes mistakes. I think JK has more than made up for the upset of book 7, though -- she wrote 6 other amazing books, she's gracious and considerate in the fandom community, and she's a principled and compassionate woman. A true role model. What's one book in comparison to the rest of her legacy? </span>  <a data-text-id="7680599343446643493" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review38710105">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks"> href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/892593996" />    <a title="Laurie U+2013A Court of BooksU+2013" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/30004027-laurie-a-court-of-books"><img alt="Laurie U+2013A Court of BooksU+2013" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1466111136p2/30004027.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/892593996?book_show_action=false">Sep 01, 2016</a>      <a title="Laurie U+2013A Court of BooksU+2013" class="user" name="Laurie U+2013A Court of BooksU+2013" href="/user/show/30004027-laurie-a-court-of-books">Laurie U+2013A Court of BooksU+2013</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9782070615360" href="/book/show/2223328.Harry_Potter_Et_Les_Reliques_De_La_Mort">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30004027-laurie-a-court-of-books?shelf=to-read-before-dying">to-read-before-dying</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30004027-laurie-a-court-of-books?shelf=read-in-french">read-in-french</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer892593996" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10637482837171355625"><i> <blockquote>U+201CDo not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all those who live without love.U+201D</blockquote> </i><br>I want to make this final review about <b> <u>Neville Longbottom</u> </b><br><br>Let me explain why. A couple years ago, I had a very disturbing conversation with a Potterhead friend.<br><br><i>Crazy friend of mine: "Did you know that Neville Longbottom was actually the real hero in Harry Potter's book?"<br>Me: "WTF ?! O_o"<br>This more and more crazy friend of mine: "Yes, I read a theory that says that JK Rowling wrote this book to make us thi</i></span>  <span id="freeText10637482837171355625" style="display:none"><i>  <blockquote>U+201CDo not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all those who live without love.U+201D</blockquote></i><br>I want to make this final review about <b>  <u>Neville Longbottom</u></b><br><br>Let me explain why. A couple years ago, I had a very disturbing conversation with a Potterhead friend.<br><br><i>Crazy friend of mine: "Did you know that Neville Longbottom was actually the real hero in Harry Potter's book?"<br>Me: "WTF ?! O_o"<br>This more and more crazy friend of mine: "Yes, I read a theory that says that JK Rowling wrote this book to make us think that Harry was the hero, but in the end you realize that it has been Neville all along" </i><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1443167451ra/16328431.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>After laughing at him and calling him crazy I went back to my business. But this idea stayed in my head during several days. I called all my Harry Potter's fan friends in the middle of the night and they all told me that this was nonsense and that I should go back to sleep.<br><br>But this wasn't enough to get it out of my head, therefore, I decided to do a Potter-movies-athlon. And I started to understand what he meant. Then I re-read all the books and I thought I needed Internet to help me understand better.<br><br>I found an awesome article online which made me realize that maybe he was right (you can check it <a href="http://www.tor.com/2013/11/19/neville-longbottom-is-the-most-important-person-in-harry-potter/" rel="nofollow">here</a> if you want)<br><br>Basically the idea is that James Potter generation and Harry Potter generation follow the same pattern. Think about it:<br>- Harry is like James, a leader of the group<br>- Ron is like Sirus, faithful friend<br>- Hermione is like Remus, really smart, a little bit outcast at first but then fully part of the group<br>- And then Neville is Peter Pettigrew. Everyone is making fun of him. Clumsy and chubby.<br>(- According to that theory, Ginny Weasley is Lilly Potter)<br><br>But this is where the story change. Neville is loyal where Peter is a coward. He stands by Harry no matter what, even if Voldemort asks him to come on his side. This theory says that JKR wanted to show that only one "side character" changes the all story. Instead of darkness and terror, Neville is the one who kills the last Horcrux (Nagini) and who defeats Voldemort, instead of joining him and betraying his friends. Just think about it, if Neville would have acted like Peter did, the ending would have been probably the opposite.<br><blockquote>  <i>U+201CWeU+2019re all going to keep fighting, Harry. You know that?U+201D</i></blockquote><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1443167506ra/16328439.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1443167507ra/16328440.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1443167507ra/16328441.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1443167507ra/16328442.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>We clearly see how his character grow during those 7 books/8 films<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1443173457ra/16329559.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></span>  <a data-text-id="10637482837171355625" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview"  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1564411256" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1564411256" />    <a title="Suanne Laqueur" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/10273177-suanne-laqueur"><img alt="Suanne Laqueur" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1442979237p2/10273177.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1564411256?book_show_action=false">Mar 01, 2016</a>      <a title="Suanne Laqueur" class="user" name="Suanne Laqueur" href="/user/show/10273177-suanne-laqueur">Suanne Laqueur</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1564411256" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer1681205468909731232">I won't get this right because I'm in two places at once. I'm finished and yet I'm starting. I feel as though I have returned from a great journey. A journey thatU+2019s only begun. I finished the last book this morning and yet I feel I donU+2019t know the whole story yet. I know there are people who make a hobby, an obsession, maybe even a career about Harry Potter lore and now I can understand why. This is not a story, itU+2019s an experience. This is the masterpiece of a truly gifted author who understands</span>  <span id="freeText1681205468909731232" style="display:none">I won't get this right because I'm in two places at once. I'm finished and yet I'm starting. I feel as though I have returned from a great journey. A journey thatU+2019s only begun. I finished the last book this morning and yet I feel I donU+2019t know the whole story yet. I know there are people who make a hobby, an obsession, maybe even a career about Harry Potter lore and now I can understand why. This is not a story, itU+2019s an experience. This is the masterpiece of a truly gifted author who understands what it means to be a great storyteller. <br /><br />Rowling understands that itU+2019s not enough to throw action and plot at a reader, but to draw them, gently and unobtrusively, into a new, believable world. Her world doesnU+2019t play by the rules of ours, but no matter. From the first chapter of book one, we are taken under RowlingU+2019s cloak of invisibility as an ordinary human and she doesnU+2019t insult our intelligence nor write down to us. She gains our trust, word by word, tale by tale. She gives us rich background, complex characters, deep emotion. At every page, we find something we relate toU+2014whether an action or a feeling. Until we are under the spell and our trust in her is absolute. Like DumbledoreU+2019s Army follows Harry, we are willing to follow wherever Rowling leads. Because we believe in her world.<br /><br />There are things I donU+2019t fully understand. Things I want to explore further. And this is why the ending is only the beginning. ItU+2019s like reaching the last level of a difficult video game, winning the prize, and now the game is open for U+201Cfree play.U+201D You can go explore to your heartU+2019s content without peril.<br /><br />And I will.<br />After all this time.<br />Always.<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="1681205468909731232" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1564411256">  <td colspan="2">    <div id="reviewTextContainer1553614019" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3603696651874678468"><b> <blockquote>"After all this time?"<br>"Always," said Snape.</blockquote> </b><i>Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows</i> broke me. I CAN'T DEAL WITH THE DEATHS OF MY FAVOURITE CHARACTERS. . . <br><br>This "review" isn't going to be a review at all, it's more of a Snape appreciation post. If you don't like him, please see yourself out right about now.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1457981650ra/18428858.gif" width="290" height="255" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>Severus Snape is my favourite character of <u>all time</u>.</b> He is such a complex and interesting character, so obbbbviously <i>The Prince's Tale</i> is my favourite chapter.<br><br>I loved Snape even before the big re</span>  <span id="freeText3603696651874678468" style="display:none"><b>  <blockquote>"After all this time?"<br>"Always," said Snape.</blockquote></b><i>Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows</i> broke me. I CAN'T DEAL WITH THE DEATHS OF MY FAVOURITE CHARACTERS. . . <br><br>This "review" isn't going to be a review at all, it's more of a Snape appreciation post. If you don't like him, please see yourself out right about now.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1457981650ra/18428858.gif" width="290" height="255" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>Severus Snape is my favourite character of <u>all time</u>.</b> He is such a complex and interesting character, so obbbbviously <i>The Prince's Tale</i> is my favourite chapter.<br><br>I loved Snape even before the big reveal in the last book. He is very clever and sly, and I just love his sarcasm and his bitterness about the world.<br><br>Snape isn't the dictionary definition of either "good" or "bad". He's in the grey area between those two polar opposites. His character taught me that it's human to make mistakes and be imperfect. Most of us aren't the chosen ones or the perfect Prince Charmings; we all have flaws, it's what makes us human. . .<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1457979722ra/18428544.gif" width="290" height="350" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br>.<br>.<br>.<br><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1534872766?book_show_action=false">My Review of Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince</a></span>  <a data-text-id="3603696651874678468" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5851949758979199259">2016<br>This book is brilliant! It ties of every little detail, it makes this series one of the best in the world.<br>All thanks to <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/1077326.J_K__Rowling" title="J.K. Rowling">J.K. Rowling</a>, who gave us the best magical experience and most loved characters.<br>Now....<br>On to the newest edition of Harry Potter. Can't wait to start <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/29056083.Harry_Potter_and_the_Cursed_Child__Harry_Potter___8_" title="Harry Potter and the Cursed Child (Harry Potter, #8) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Cursed Child</a><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470124889i/19889407._SX540_.jpg" width="1000" height="400" alt="Cursed Child" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>2015<br>This truly is the best series that I've ever read!<br>Re-reading it just convinced me once more of J.K Rowling's brilliance! She gave us magical childhoods, and much deeper things to think about</span>  <span id="freeText5851949758979199259" style="display:none">2016<br>This book is brilliant! It ties of every little detail, it makes this series one of the best in the world.<br>All thanks to <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/1077326.J_K__Rowling" title="J.K. Rowling">J.K. Rowling</a>, who gave us the best magical experience and most loved characters.<br>Now....<br>On to the newest edition of Harry Potter. Can't wait to start <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/29056083.Harry_Potter_and_the_Cursed_Child__Harry_Potter___8_" title="Harry Potter and the Cursed Child (Harry Potter, #8) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Cursed Child</a><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470124889i/19889407._SX540_.jpg" width="1000" height="400" alt="Cursed Child" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>2015<br>This truly is the best series that I've ever read!<br>Re-reading it just convinced me once more of J.K Rowling's brilliance! She gave us magical childhoods, and much deeper things to think about in our adulthood. <br>She transported us to a place so magical and real, with a story full of witt, laughter, tears, and lessons to never forget. For this I will forever be thankful! <br>Thanks J.K Rowling for all your time, effort and persistence to get this series out into the world.</span>  <a data-text-id="5851949758979199259" href="#" Ama konumuz bu deU+011Fil :D SU+0131rlar OdasU+0131'nU+0131 defalarca bir CD'ciden kiralayU+0131p kuzenimle kaU+00E7 kere izlediU+011Fimizi asla unutamam. Benim hayatU+0131mU+0131n bU+00FCyU+00FCk bir parU+00E7asU+0131ydU+0131 bu filmler. 5. filme kadar hiU+00E7 aksatmadan izledim filmleri ama daha sonra kitaplarU+0131nU+0131 okumaya karar verdim ve en az filmleri kadar iyi olduU+011Funu gU+00F6rdU+00FCm.<br /><br />Bu son kitaba da baU+015Flarken U+00E7ok heyecanlU+0131 ama aynU+0131 zamanda buruktum. J.K. Rowling'in beni hayal kU+0131rU+0131klU+0131 U+011F U+0131na uU+011FratmayacaU+011F U+0131nU+0131 biliyordum. Seri mU+00FCthiU+015F, U+015FanU+0131na yakU+0131 U+015F U+0131r bir finalle bitti fakat aklU+0131mda bir kaU+00E7 soru var. Rowling'in nasU+0131l yetiU+015FtirildiU+011Fini merak ediyorum. NasU+0131l bir ortamda bU+00FCyU+00FCdU+00FC? <br /><br />Bu son kitap aU+011FzU+0131ma sU+0131 U+00E7tU+0131. BildiU+011Fin mahvetti beni. TU+00FCm seri U+00F6yle bir baU+011FlanmU+0131 U+015F, U+00F6yle bir kurgulanmU+0131 U+015F ki inanamU+0131yorsunuz. 'Bir U+015Fey olmalU+0131! Bir yerde bir kusur olmalU+0131!' Ta ilk iki kitaba kadar geri dU+00F6nU+00FC U+015Flerin yapU+0131ldU+0131 U+011F U+0131, burada baU+015Flayan olaylarU+0131n sonuU+00E7landU+0131rU+0131ldU+0131 U+011F U+0131 ve aslU+0131nda her U+015Feyin U+00E7ok farklU+0131 olduU+011Funu mantU+0131klU+0131 bir U+015Fekilde anlatU+0131lmasU+0131 kurgunun kusursuzluU+011Fu deU+011Fil de nedir?<br /><br />Geriye dU+00F6nU+00FCp baktU+0131 U+011F U+0131mda bir hazine gU+00F6rU+00FCyorum. Daima benimle olacak ve unutulmayacak bir hazine... Son 90 sayfada gU+00F6z yaU+015FlarU+0131ma engel olamadU+0131m. Tekrar tekrar aU+011FladU+0131m. En U+00E7ok Snape mahvetti beni sanU+0131rU+0131m. BaU+015F U+0131ndan beri nefret ettiU+011Fim o adam... Son 5 sayfayU+0131 ise zor okudum.  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1218750132" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1218750132" />    <a title="Tally" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/28351026-tally"><img alt="Tally" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1411618047p2/28351026.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1218750132?book_show_action=false">Jan 18, 2016</a>      <a title="Tally" class="user" name="Tally" href="/user/show/28351026-tally">Tally</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28351026-tally?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1218750132" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17492054532780118160">I will never find the perfect words to describe how I feel about the Harry Potter series. It's an incredible story, everybody knows that.<br /><br />I am not unique in my connection with these books. When I was younger, I would wait with excited anticipation for the next HP book to come out. When it did, I would hole myself up in my room and devour it in a day. I had read other books that I'd liked well enough prior to HP, but this was different. It was that feverish feeling you get when you're so wrapped u</span>  <span id="freeText17492054532780118160" style="display:none">I will never find the perfect words to describe how I feel about the Harry Potter series. It's an incredible story, everybody knows that.<br /><br />I am not unique in my connection with these books. When I was younger, I would wait with excited anticipation for the next HP book to come out. When it did, I would hole myself up in my room and devour it in a day. I had read other books that I'd liked well enough prior to HP, but this was different. It was that feverish feeling you get when you're so wrapped up in a story. It's the absolute love you have for the characters, and the spectacular world-building that stretches your imagination. It cemented my love for reading.<br /><br />Twelve years later, I re-read the series, finishing with this last installment. This time, I read it slower. I wanted to savor every bit of it. And it was exactly as good as I remembered.</span>  <a data-text-id="17492054532780118160" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1121542798" />    <a title="Brooke" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/5242679-brooke"><img alt="Brooke" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1121542798?book_show_action=false">Dec 30, 2014</a>      <a title="Brooke" class="user" name="Brooke" href="/user/show/5242679-brooke">Brooke</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5242679-brooke?shelf=kindle-reads">kindle-reads</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1121542798" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer14207834967302330145">WELL I FINISHED THE HARRY POTTER SERIES!!!<br /><br />Three years ago I decided to finally pick up a little book called, "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone." Granted I wasn't in middle school or being read to before bed: nope I was 21 years old and enjoyed them just as much if maybe not more for waiting. <br /><br />I know this has been said plenty of times before me, but JK Rowling created a legacy for herself with writing these books. The first four were so wonderful and even though the next 3 books (plot-wise) w</span>  <span id="freeText14207834967302330145" style="display:none">WELL I FINISHED THE HARRY POTTER SERIES!!!<br /><br />Three years ago I decided to finally pick up a little book called, "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone." Granted I wasn't in middle school or being read to before bed: nope I was 21 years old and enjoyed them just as much if maybe not more for waiting. <br /><br />I know this has been said plenty of times before me, but JK Rowling created a legacy for herself with writing these books. The first four were so wonderful and even though the next 3 books (plot-wise) went downhill for me, this ending had me smiling and reminded me why these books are so much more than children's tales. <br /><br />There are so many great moments throughout this series and these characters are some I am never going to find and love in other books as much as I do in these books. <br />Hagrid always remained a favorite, along with Ron Weasley and of course Dumbledore!! The boarding of the scarlet train to Hogwarts scenes were another magical yet simply beautiful piece to the story. HEDWIG!! Hermonine and the house elves, Christmas at Hogwarts, Hagrid's dragon Norbert, and the wise and wonderful words of Dumbledore about love for each other. <br /><br />It's a bittersweet feeling completing this series. ALL WAS WELL.</span>  <a data-text-id="14207834967302330145" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext href="/review/list/7788355-karen?shelf=re-read-quite-a-few-times">re-read-quite-a-few-times</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/7788355-karen?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1454673383" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer11695625096268928168">I closed this book and finished my reread last night at about midnight. My heart was heavy and I've been in a bit of a funk ever since. What am I going to do now? I've been going to Hogwarts, fighting off dementors, meeting up with my friends from the DA, and knocking about with Harry, Ron and Hermione for the past 3 1/2 months!! And now....? I have no more Harry Potter books to read. <br /><br />Even though I had several other books I should have been reading, Harry won me over, and my brain couldn't focus</span>  <span id="freeText11695625096268928168" style="display:none">I closed this book and finished my reread last night at about midnight. My heart was heavy and I've been in a bit of a funk ever since. What am I going to do now? I've been going to Hogwarts, fighting off dementors, meeting up with my friends from the DA, and knocking about with Harry, Ron and Hermione for the past 3 1/2 months!! And now....? I have no more Harry Potter books to read. <br /><br />Even though I had several other books I should have been reading, Harry won me over, and my brain couldn't focus on anything else unless I gave in and just picked up whatever HP book I was reading. <br /><br />I'm so thankful that J K Rowling has decided to continue with this world and we have 3 more movies of <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/41899.Fantastic_Beasts_and_Where_to_Find_Them" title="Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them by Newt Scamander">Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them</a> and a play about Harry's youngest son. Whew. Maybe I'll be out of my funk by then.</span>  <a data-text-id="11695625096268928168" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1454673383">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1454673383" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1454673383&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/136251.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1454673383'><a id="like_count_review_1454673383" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1454673383?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">21 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1454673383" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1454673383" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button comments</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/1454673383?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=3">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1454673383' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/1454673383/comments?reverse=true">View 2 comments</a><span </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1210860250" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1210860250" />    <a title="Jonathan" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/6313408-jonathan"><img alt="Jonathan" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1478230200p2/6313408.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1210860250?book_show_action=false">Feb 27, 2015</a>      <a title="Jonathan" class="user" name="Jonathan" href="/user/show/6313408-jonathan">Jonathan</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9781408835029" href="/book/show/18457987-harry-potter-the-deathly-hallows">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6313408-jonathan?shelf=favourite-series">favourite-series</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6313408-jonathan?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6313408-jonathan?shelf=favourites">favourites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6313408-jonathan?shelf=worldbuilding">worldbuilding</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1210860250" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer12599201797386723423">As a whole series, my average rating for the series ends up roughly around 4 stars. This is purely because once the series gets over its initial roughness, keeping the charm and developing the characters it becomes a very solid and imaginative series. It may not be the 'epic' that some people are looking for in their fantasy - but like <i>The Chronicles of Narnia</i> its a quirky and appealing little series. <br /><br />Let's be honest: nothing I say or do not say about this series will persuade or dissuade anyone</span>  <span id="freeText12599201797386723423" style="display:none">As a whole series, my average rating for the series ends up roughly around 4 stars. This is purely because once the series gets over its initial roughness, keeping the charm and developing the characters it becomes a very solid and imaginative series. It may not be the 'epic' that some people are looking for in their fantasy - but like <i>The Chronicles of Narnia</i> its a quirky and appealing little series. <br /><br />Let's be honest: nothing I say or do not say about this series will persuade or dissuade anyone from reading these books if they put their mind to either standpoint. All I can say is how I found the novels and with all honesty I found that they improved so much that I think I will actually miss not having another book in the series to move on and read. <br /><br />I'm a huge reader of fantasy and have been since my mother read <i>The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe</i> to me as a six year old child (I went on to read the novel for myself the following year). There's something about the way a truly great fantasy novel can take you to a whole other world (same with sci-fi) and yet remind you about real world concepts, themes, emotions and values that is appealing. So, I admit that when other children grew up on Harry Potter, I grew up on the novels which preceded Harry Potter. I grew up in Narnia, Middle Earth, Wonderland, Neverland and so on. So as I saw the hype for the Harry Potter series (coupled with the fact that my parents thought the books a touch too dark for my age) I may have decided to avoid reading them, thinking that they were copycats of other, better, books. How snobbish of me.<br /><br />I would easily add this series (for the improvement, character building, world etc.) to my list of unique fantasy series. Of course this would be a list featuring the before mentioned books and also anything by Brandon Sanderson (particularly his Mistborn books), The Wheel of Time (if you don't mind looooong drawn out epic fantasy tales) and The Name of the Wind (as far as it has gone till now). I definitely am willing to recommend any books that you might like if you grew up on Harry Potter or anything similar. <br /><br />Pardon my ramblings, all I wish to say is that I was very impressed with the series after being less than so with the first two and a half books. The other four fully make the most of the promise of the first few books however and therefore create works of fiction which perform all that I believe literature should do.<br /><br />In the novels there are subtle and nuanced reflections on education and the influence of governments and politics on daily life. Rowling seems to imply that while government is a great thing behind the scenes to keep the world running there are times when it meddles in the greater good. Leonard Nimoy (RIP) passed away earlier and he once said (in character) that 'the needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few'. I believe this is the concept that Rowling wished to convey about education and government. The few are in power and authority and it is their job to fulfill the needs of the many, not their own.<br /><br />I also love the final part of this novel with its very Christian message. In some ways Harry becomes a rough Christ figure in these novels (which has lead to the book's fair share of criticism such as how can you mix a message of faith with magic etc.) with how his love and sacrifice for his friends enables him to be able to defeat dark magic. It's a similar theme to that used in The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe but in a different way and I loved how it was used here. I was often told that the books were so non-Christian with the magic and everything but this conclusion is very Christian in how it conveys that evil is created through fear and a desire to become like God (all-powerful like Voldemort attempts to become) and that only sacrificial love can truly defeat the curse of evil. It's a great message and I would definitely not hide these books or ban them, I would encourage children to read them and then ask them questions about those themes!<br /><br />All in all, I definitely enjoyed the books and have also been enjoying the movies simultaneously. I wish in some senses that I had read them sooner and definitely recommend them for the story. Don't be sucked in by the hype, but do read them for their beautiful little story and thematic expression!</span>  <a data-text-id="12599201797386723423" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1210860250">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1210860250" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1210860250&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/136251.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1210860250'><a id="like_count_review_1210860250" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1210860250?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">20 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1210860250" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1210860250" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=20&rating[page]=3&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=1210860250&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_1210860250" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 1210860250, true, &#39;&#39;);
